While the game is most definitely largely inspired by Zelda, I honestly got some very slight vibes of the original MSX Metal Gear just in that most of the game is spent going around exploring one large building, being a castle in Ittle Dew and Outer Heaven in Metal Gear. 38638504.review:
[b]Ittle Dew[/b] is a zelda-like game which focuses more on the puzzles than on story and exploration. The game has a lot of humor and parody elements though it manages to have a personality of its own. The characters and enemies are charismatic and collectible cards with info about characters add to that. The graphics in this game are really good, you can see how much love and care went into drawing game world and strange creatures which inhabit it. Sound design is ok, but in some hard levels it becomes a bit tiring listening to one song on repeat. 

[b]Pros:[/b]
- Amazing hand-drawn graphics
- Good humor
- Mindblowing puzzles (Master Dungeon)
- Nonlinear levels

[b]Cons:[/b]
- Short

Ittle Dew turned out to be a real hidden gem for me. Hope it will be the same to you.

38263122.review:
Ittle Dew presented a series of interesting challenges one should expect from a rogue-like adventure game. Less emphasis was placed on combat and a lot more was placed on environmental puzzles. A great many challenges were actually difficult, but optional. What little story was written was an amusing, self-aware commentary on the game itself.

Usually, full completion of a game is a chore for me. I end up taking a long break and coming back when I feel like grinding. Fortunately, Ittle Dew isn't about grinding. It's about learning. The more you know, the better off you are. Your protagonist is a powerless little person with a worthless animal companion, but the knowledge you gain makes you hilariously dangerous.

I wholeheartedly approve of the adorable art style, playful sound design, and even the personality of my protagonist. It isn't often that I enjoy a game like this so much, and I'm eager to get the sequel eventually to see if it measures up to the original.

Finally, good luck with the Master Cave. I really mean it. It is ridiculous, but I love it.

38075874.review:
Awful game 

I had seen gameplay footage of it the style seems interesting from first glance so i bought it out of curiosity expecting an adventure to be had like the zelda franchise especially like zelda 2 link to the past which i loved.

It tries to mix puzzle and single player rpg elements together from the worst of both worlds. Everything was terrible besides the art design with the lighthearted tone to it is a matter of preference so i give it a its just me. But everything else from controls, lag, enemy AI, puzzles and how its played in general is very rage inducing and annoying.

The puzzle elements are just simple puzzles that can be solved with thought but to no avail does the game reward you for doing so it trolls you with useless cards and such that you dont need. Compared to items you find along the main path which is gold and needed health scrap paper that you need anyways.

The problem lies on there is no indication of that chest is needed or not usually because it is present on the main path anyway with some side chamber most of the time you will probably be drawn to the frustrating puzzle element with the enemy placement over and over since the puzzles are usually prone to having dead ends if you mess up one step making you exit and enter the same roon having to fight the same enemies and taking hits till finally you have another shot at the frustrating puzzle until you succeed only to be slapped in the face as it was just a card.

Its like trying to do an exam but with shit flying at you. Its not fun and the depth perception of the game is terrible to say the least. I can never tell if i can hit an enemy of the plane that i am at i only can hit them accurately from the sides as i always end up being to early on swinging downwards or upwards.

The enemy AI and combat is cheap too just by touching an enemy counts as a half a heart of damage and even so they move and change direction very suddenly even if they have just 1 or 2 health their patterns of their movement especially enemies with more health than 1 hit point is unacceptable as there is no pattern and they have a invincibility frame to stop chaining hits making your firepower essensially useless. 

The hit detection is terrible its pinpoint for you as you have to be on the exact same plane as them and considering you only can face 4 directions and no diagionals its really stiff and outright unfair. For enemies its another story just by touching a single pixel of your body you will take a hit doesnt matter where if its the edge of the hair or foot it still counts to hurting you. The enemies should have an attack animation and pattern where it can be telegraphed to the player fairly so the player knows how to handle certain enemies instead of brute forcing and with a bit of luck they wont change direction to where you are.

The "boss battles" are not boss battles a boss battle in an adventure rpg is a boss with a health bar that does certain patterns telegraphed to the player fairly to an extent of whether it will be easy to hard depending on the player's equipment and position of the story. That will be a boss that should exist a boss that is fair on challenge and it penalizes you for getting hit from screwing up or not recognizing the openings.
In ittle dew nope it says fuck all that your weapon is useless its puzzle elements yes but its a endurance round of once again cheap tricks of throwing puzzle elements in a small opening which is timed while your struggling with the control scheme and other problems mentioned usually youll end up missing your opportunity to do damage as its so pinpoint and short along with game requiring the player to know the pattern at first while your getting your ass kicked trying to figure out what to do as hitting the boss doesnt work.

You hit the boss 1 or 2 times with something you find whether a bomb or teleporting their projectile into them but the gap is so small and there is no clear pattern with some of them that the cycle can repeat so many times due to you missing and getting hit that youll be frustrated over the game instead of having satisfaction doing damage to a boss.

Some even attack really suddenly like the first boss which charges when you are in the x and y axis of the screen considering you are in harms way all the time and the bomb that you are supposed to harm him with takes long to explode usually he will charge at you and youll take a hit while the bomb does nothing with you repeating the same cycle again till the boss is dead.

It combines with worst of both worlds and i am really upset because i was fooled thinking i will have a swell singleplayer puzzle solving adventuring time in a game. But it misses core aspects with rewarding the player for hardwork, fair challenge, leveling system to scale with skill, proper enemies, fluid controls, fair hit detection, puzzle elements that can be reset easily without annoyance of losing progress and respawning enemies just to annoy the player, good boss battle fight sequence, currency system and intriguing adventure.

It completely missed everything making ittle dew itself a chore and a frustrating one at that to play due to the unmerited damage and deaths the player will be experiencing from bad elements that are abundantly present in this game.

Its like if resident evil 4 had a bad control scheme, resets puzzles by sending you back to where the area begins with all the enemies back in their place, just touching an enemy hurts you for half you life bar, bosses have such a small opening backed up along with other enemies and cant be hurt by gunfire but be some obscure puzzle element that you wont even know what to do. enemies cant be knocked back considering that have an invincibility frame so if they are in midswing a shot to the face wont stun or stop the swing and you take a hit, chests with no purpose but looked important at first glance, enemies just magically poof away when they take enough damage and no progression in weaponry but only needed items for a certain puzzle element to make the game more of a chore instead of rewarding the player with new hard earned equipment, currency doesnt make sense and you need currency anyway to get past a certain point in the game where it introduces more puzzle elements along with the shit your juggling at once to make it more of a thought process in a shitstorm. Imagine playing an alternate version of RE4 with these features you will be PISSED. 

I know re4 was supposed to be hard in some ways as its survival horror but if you make it downright unfair and let the player take unmerited damage and impossible expectations everyone will be turned of by it and simply saying "Its supposed to be hard" is not a fair excuse when the gameplay is also unsatisfying in general.

Thats what this game is unsatisfying and rage inducing as it is nothing but an abomination of mixing the worst of puzzles and adventure rpg elemets.

36433032.review:
[h1] More Than Just a Zelda Clone [/h1]

I love "The Legend of Zelda" series. They're great adventure, action games that any fan of the genre can appreciate. Ittle Dew takes inspiration from the top-down, 2D Zelda games to the point where if you reskinned Ittle Dew with the same textures as "A Link to the Past" you wouldn't be able to tell the difference. On the surface Ittle Dew appears to take more than inspiration, and I'm sure most would even call Ittle Dew a Zelda clone. You explore dungeons, get items from the dungeons, solve the dungeons' puzzles, defeat a boss, use the item from the dungeons to progess further into the game, and eventually it all ends with a final epic boss battle. There's hearts to replenish your life, a fairy-esque follower who guides you on your travels, old men giving you cryptic messages, statues resembling those from the original Zelda 1, hell, you even begin the game waking up from a deep sleep as Zelda games traditonally do. However, to label Ittle Dew simply as just a Zelda clone would be a diservice to this game, because Ittle Dew's puzzles are more intricate, creative, and difficult than any Zelda puzzle to date. Now I know that's a bold statement, but think for a moment, what was the last zelda puzzle that really made you think and put your puzzle solving skills to the test? I can think of only one, and anybody who played "Twilight Princess" will know exactly which puzzle I'm talking about. That's one puzzle. In a game series spanning more than 25 years there's only one puzzle that tests you. Ittle Dew regularly makes you scratch your head and 20 minutes later you're still left scratching.

If you like puzzle games and zelda, check this one out, you won't regret it.

36401173.review: Ittle Dew was a cute and snarky Zelda-esque game.  Short (achievement for under 3 hours and another for under 15 minutes, speedrunners), but has replay value in completing with specific weapons only etc.

35525719.review:
Ludosity, you have become one of favourite indie developers, as of late. I’ve played several of your games now and they’ll all good. Guess this means I’m giving this a recommendation already but I still must explain the pros and cons of this game so let’s begin.

Story:
Ittle Dew and her buddy Tippsie were just relaxing on their raft when they get stranded on an island. After some exploring, the duo meet an item carver named Itan Carver who can make them a raft off the island but they must find an artefact in the nearby castle as payment so our adventurers must go find it.

Not much to talk story wise as it’s just an adventure so lets talk characters which isn’t much but it’s something. Ittle is an enjoyable little adventurer who’s very blunt about things like eating what she find on the ground or admitting not understanding what someone said. And there’s Tippsie, her flying fox buddy who gives tips with a tone of “Really, do I have to help.”. Together they make a fun duo, poking fun at the weird things on the island and each other.

And some of the enemies have some personality even if some of them don’t have an intro, like the stone heads who are afraid of heights. But my favourites are the Jennys  who each have a little personalty quark like the frog being laid back.

Gameplay:
I’ve never played a Legend of Zelda game before. Not even the new ones for handheld. Now that we got that out of the way lets talk about the game.

The first few minutes do a decent job of showing how the game works up to your first chest, like pushing blocks, lighting your stick to light bonfires, the different doors that open by defeat all enemies or turning on all switches, etc.  But in order to get to the dungeons, you need money from the castle and after the first chest, you free to do the first dungeon or explore to get more money. And that’s one of the interesting things about this game which is the castle is non-linear as you only need to buy two items to get to the end.

The dungeons are really just tutorials on how the items you get work, and you temporary lose your other items you bought so it’s like being thrown in the middle depth of the pool and have to use your head to get out. I like this as it teaches you how each items works and with all the other mechanics in each dungeon, can teach you how it works with the other items like freezing blocks to break them with you fire sword. And of course each dungeon ends with a boss fight and to be honest, only the forest boss and the final boss are good since they both are test of what you can do. The fire boss was very underwhelming with how you barely him and the ice boss was good but it uses one of the most important ice mechanics you weren’t thought in the dungeon so I had to use a tip to figure it out.

And besides the main dungeons, there are little dungeon rooms just outside them that can teach you more about your new items with it’s cleaver puzzles and reward you with a health upgrade or a card that’s just for flavour. And there’s even a super optional dungeon that have some nasty puzzles, making you think outside the box and making you use ideas you didn’t know you can do.

This is clearly a speed running game too as not only do you just have to do two dungeons but there are also shortcuts that are hard to unlock but can really cut a good chuck of time from the dungeon. But I did found one flaw where if you want to a particular run, it’s very easy to screw yourself over. For me, I wanted to do the one where you don’t kill any Jenny’s and decided to get the fire sword first, but as I explore the castle I couldn’t the chests I needed to get the ice wand so I had to start over. 

Presentation:
The music is a mix bag for me. While I like the music for the outside and the castle theme are good, I found the dungeon music to be pretty forgettable. 

I love the art in this game. Everything just looks so cute, from Ittle and Tippsie, to the Jenny’s to the fishbuns to even the crystals and blocks. I think it looks really good.

Verdict:
I admit some puzzle were pretty hard but this is a good game. Wonder if Ittle Dew 2 be better?
9/10

34108837.review:
Small award winning indie game that most people never heard about. 

Well... At least I never heard about it until my friend recommended it to me.
Very small and interesting puzzle game that can be finished in 2-3 hours and first try and 15 minutes or less though speed run. 

You have 3 different weapon you can buy. Fire to break things, Ice to freeze things and portal to teleport things. Sounds simple enough? There are lots of puzzles in this game is anything but simple. I had a ton of trouble getting that last 100 gold to buy portal wand and I ended up finishing the game without it. It's a trust test of your IQ to see if you can solve everything quickly or not.

Music is well done with some interesting tone to fit every zone, Graphics are wobble hand drawn type and It's simple but lovable. Story is there but doesn't really matter much since it's very short anyways. Jokes fills the entire game in every conversation and you will chuckle over and over.

Achievemnt hunter beware.. this game takes many run to get 100% as it require you to finish game with any combonation of 2 weapons or 3 weapons.

9/10 well done indie and well deserved 9. IF you think you are smart and you got a few hours on your hand. You must play this.

33053063.review:
This is a pretty solid game. A clever streamlined parody of LoZ with heavier focus on puzzles.

Thematically it's a parody of classic top down Legend of Zelda. It has pretty funny writing, and I like the style. A lot of games with a similar silly aesthetic are also kinda gross, but this one thankfully isn't.

On the gameplay front it's very streamlined. For instance, to view signs or have your character comment on things, you just walk up to them. No pressing an interact button is needed, and it doesn't make you stop moving to read it. There are multiple routes you can take, but no backtracking is needed. As posted on a sign outside a dungeon: "Dear adventurer: for your convenience, there are no items or chests you can miss in the dungeons." And there are no keys you have to find in one room and take halfway across the dungeon to use in another room you saw earlier. The overworld is another story, though. There are several optional one-room mini dungeons scattered about, and a few of them you do have to come back later to clear.

It has several ways to finish the game (you can acquire your items in any order), supports shortcuts (if you're up to the challenge puzzle in the way), cute graphics and sounddesign.

Even the mechanics are mostly mechanics you've probably seen before.

But this game IS fun. If that's what you're looking for, give it a buy and enjoy.

32231278.review:
[h1]Unschuldiges Abenteuer im Zelda Stil [/h1]

Auch wenn das Spiel wie ein Kinderspiel aussieht, kommen hier wohl auch ältere Spieler an ihre kognitiven Grenzen!

[b]Gameplay[/b]
"Ittle Dew" ist ein Top-Down Spiel und erinnert vom Gameplay sehr stark an "The Legend of Zelda". Wir prügeln uns durch niedliche Gegner, spielen mit Bomben und müssen viele Rätsel lösen. Hierbei sammeln wir im Schloss Gold, womit wir uns wiederum die drei Gegenstände im Laden kaufen können. Kaufen ist allerdings das falsche Wort, der Händler schickt uns nämlich stattdessen zu einem der drei Dungeons, in denen wir unser neues Item erstmal ausprobieren können. Mit der neuen Ausrüstung kommen wir wiederum im Schloss weiter und nähern uns so dem Boss und den sammelbaren Monsterkarten. Auch weitere Lebensherzen lassen sich in Form von kleinen Papierstücken sammeln und die Teleportstationen innerhalb des Schlosses finden. Besonders erwähnenswert ist, dass man alle wichtigen Rätsel auch in beliebiger Kombination von nur 2 der 3 Items lösen kann. Hat man alle 3, kann man noch die Meisterhöhle und den Kompostdungeon mit zusätzlichen Rätseln aufsuchen.

Das Spiel wirkt zwar kindlich, die Rätsel sind oft aber ziemlich knifflig, insbesondere mit nur 2 Gegenständen. Ich hatte auch im Kampf einige Schwierigkeiten und auch dabei, den richtigen Weg zu finden. Dabei ist es zusätzlich anstrengend, dass die Gegner nach jedem Neubetreten respawnen. Da ich "The Legend of Zelda" nie intensiv gespielt habe, kann ich keinen direkten Vergleich anstellen, jedoch ist das Gameplay sehr fair und hat mir sehr gut gefallen. Man kann nichts verpassen und bekommt vom Spiel eine sehr gute Hilfstellung.

[b]Story[/b]
Die Geschichte ist nicht besonders tiefgreifend. Ittle und ihre "Fee" Tippsie stranden auf einer Insel und suchen das Abenteuer. Der einzige andere Mensch auf der Insel, der Händler, bietet ihnen ein Floß gegen ein im Schloss verstecktes Artefakt. Weiterhin kommt es zu echt lustigen Dialogen zwischen der kindlichen Ittle und der Heiltranksüchtigen Tippsie, sowie auch zwischen Ittle und manchen Gegnern. Das Spiel hat durch die Charaktere seinen ganz eigenen Charm und hat mich desöfteren zum Grinsen gebracht.

[b]Grafik/Sound[/b]
"Ittle Dew" wirkt durchgängig wie gezeichnet. Die Gegner wirken sehr niedlich, lustig und generell wackeln viele Texturen, wodurch das Spiel wesentlich frischer und lebendiger wirkt. Auch ist das Spiel sehr, sehr farbenfroh.

Die Melodie ist sehr heiter und passt sich der Umgebung gut an. Sie ist sehr simpel, aber passt einfach zum Gesamtspiel.


[b]Fazit[/b]
Das Spiel ist zwar in gewisser Weise eine Parodie, jedoch ist der Spielstil auch nach all den Jahren noch erfrischend und insbesondere in "Ittle Dew" gut umgesetzt. Die Grafik und Melodie laden zum Weiterspielen ein und generell ist das ganze Spiel einfach niedlich. Das Spiel badet in einer unschuldigen und kindgerechten Atmossphäre und genau das macht das Spiel besonders. "Ittle Dew" hat zu seinem Release große Wellen in der Indiewelt geschlagen und ich kann dem positiven Feedback nur zustimmen. Dieses Spiel ist eine wahre Indieperle und bekommt von mir eine volle Empfehlung!



Wenn dir das Review gefallen hat, würde ich mich freuen, wenn du meiner Kuratorgruppe auf Steam folgst, um auch meine Reviews zu anderen Spielen zu bekommen: http://steamcommunity.com/groups/Drakeschool

31609810.review:
I bought this game during the last Steam Summer Sale, and frankly, the fact that I paid anything at all for this rudimentary 'Zelda' parody makes me feel ripped off.

'Ittle Dew' is a 2D overhead adventure game designed as a blatantly-obvious homage to 'A Link to the Past'. Maybe "homage" is the wrong word, since many aesthetic elements are lifted straight from 'ALTTP'. A fact evident just by looking at 'Ittle Dew's' protagonist. It's a wonder Nintendo never sued. 

While 'A Link to the Past' was a classic, fun, robust game that could hook first-time adventurers for dozens of hours, though, the world of 'Ittle Dew' is strangely barren. There's pretty much no story to speak of, zero character development. Combat is uninspired and suffers from hit detection issues when using certain weapons. Add to that, I managed to complete the game with every collectible in 7 hours on my first playthrough (that's IN SPITE of challening the secret extra cave). No multiplayer or DLC to extend the game's replay value either. 

Funny thing is, 'Ittle Dew' seems to know it's lame, as the title is replete with self-aware, self-deprecating humor. So in summary:

Pros: 
- Handrawn art style beautiful in its simplicity
- Ocassionally funny, self-aware dialogue

Cons:
- Obscenely short length
- No replay value (beyond a few Achievements)
- No plot
- Overeliance on block puzzles
- Hit detection issues

Conclusion: 'Ittle Dew' started out as a free game made using 'Game Maker', and that's how it should've stayed. Even if it has its charms, there's just too little content to justify paying $9.99 for.

31148894.review:
An absolute blast, I loved every second. That said, everyone here has already sung its praises. I like to talk about game scripts and writing. So if you're looking for a full review, everyone else here has got a pretty good handle on what's good and bad about the game. I wanna talk about its writing.

Played it just coming off of Yooka Laylee, which had one of the worst scripts I've ever encountered in a game, but Ittle Dew is comparably comedic, childish and meta-oriented, with 4th-wall breaking jokes coming out of sardonic, goofy characters. The degree to which Ittle Dew trounces Yooka Laylee in its execution, however, is startling.

Ittle Dew's writing has three things going for it that make the script not just lovable and silly, but exceptional:
-A clever Double Act
-Unobtrusiveness
-A well-thought out balance of cynicism and heart.

A good Double Act is always based on the chemistry between two disparate characters. Abbott and Costello: A no-nonsense straight-man and a clowny, intentionally-frustrating goof. The reason they bounce off each other is because they can create increasing comedic energy from the simple act of interaction.
Straight man says a baseline for Goof to comment upon, which straight-man replies to with frustration, which goof replies to with knowing snark and back and forth, a consistent volley of energy that takes a decent amount of time to grow old because neither of characters ever venture into 'unlikeable'.

This disparate natures of Ittle and Tippsie are naive, curious energy and sarcastic, exhausted wit. Ittle can respond with curiosity, to which Tippsie responds with cynical resentment, to which Ittle responds with frustrated surprise, to which Tippsie responds with sarcastic acknowledgement, which is a funny volley over and over again, and because they're both characters who are, if not fleshed out, then at least well-established and full of interesting, fun characteristics.

As for unobtrusiveness: Ittle Dew's dialogue has a habit of appearing when a new enemy or concept is introduced and right before boss battles. Exceptions are rare. This means that dialogue only appears distinctly at moments when more information would be desirable and, very importantly, only while the game is continuing to be interesting. In the middle of a slow area, where frustration is high and concentration/patience is important, there is a 0% chance of dialogue interrupting anything or presenting itself as a time-waster.

Lastly: the game is very meta, but never at its own expense. It's a game who's storyline is "We've arrived on Video Game Island, I wonder what's in store for us", and while it makes a few cracks at typical genre conventions, it never accuses itself of not being fun (something that Yooka Laylee did fairly and unfortunately often), it takes as gospel the fact that the player has shown up to have fun and has a love for the genre, and thus mirrors the player's enthusiasm by taking loving jabs and a genuine enthusiasm for the premise and world and gameplay.

The ending is character-oriented, which may seem like a weird choice in a plot that's essentially non-existent, until you realize that without the formality of plot, the things we've grown to love over the game's runtime are the gameplay itself and the characters who were enjoying it.

It's a delightful game with a delightful story and it doesn't need to be any more than that. Hearty recommend.

30892397.review:
Ittle Dew is a top-down puzzle game with light action elements.  The game's main castle is non-linear, and depending on where you go, you can get money, which you use to obtain one of three pieces of equipment.  The equipment can be used to advance further, get more equipment, and so on.  The non-linear design guarantees that everyone can approach the game in a variety of ways.  This brings a surprising amount of replayability to what would otherwise be a linear game.

The primary focus of the gameplay is in the puzzling.  The puzzles are well thought-out, and even if you know you have the right equipment to solve a particular room, it can require a clever approach and out of the box thinking to advance.  Most of them use elements of sliding block puzzling, but thanks to the unique elements of the game, they feel like much more.

The humor is great as well.  While the game is excellent from its level design and puzzles, the humor is the cherry on top that makes it a masterpiece.  The sound and art contribute to the theme, and I can't possibly recommend this game enough.

If you want puzzles, this game will scratch that itch.  If you want action, while it has some of that, it's not going to put up that much of a challenge.  Either way, pick it up.  You will be surprised that more games aren't like this one.

30888055.review: After discovering this game from a passing mention in forum discussion, I knew that it looked like just the sort of game that I'd enjoy, being very much inspired by the puzzle elements of 2D [I]Zelda[/I] (my favourite game series). Very fun puzzle game that never takes itself too seriously, and the Zelda inspired gameplay is boiled down to simple puzzles and adventuring and a few bits of cute flavor here and there. A lot of the main game puzzles aren't too difficult especially since they're usually designed around 2 of the 3 items you can obtain within the game, and using all 3 items makes most of the puzzles trivial. Where the main game really shines is that you can choose to completely ignore the 3rd item and try to finish the game with 2 items, resulting in different puzzle scenarios and pathways you can take.

The only problem that annoys me about this game though, is that some of the hardest puzzles require you to have quick reflexes and some luck in order for you to finish them. Fortunately, most of those puzzles are extra challenges and do not stand between you and the final boss.

30131758.review:
A masterful parody of the 2D Legend of Zelda games, ittle Dew (lowercase i) takes the well-known item-based puzzle solving of the series and polishes it to a mirror shine, wrapped up in a cheerful and smoothly-animated art style, while layering on enjoyable helpings of wry wit as it pokes fun at traditional video game conventions.  Who keeps putting hearts into rocks, anyways?

ittle Dew never wastes time and is built as tight as a drum.  There’s no sprawling overworld, no overly dramatic plot, and no tedious filler; it gets in, delivers the puzzles, and gets out before wearing out its welcome.  The game is comprised of three short item dungeons (which can be completed in any order), a dozen or so optional puzzle rooms, and a central non-linear castle that is revisited multiple times as the player gains more items.  A first run through the game is a casual five hours (more if going for all the secrets), and optional second-run challenges are also available for the minimalist and speedrunning players.

The puzzles are a masterwork in this game, relying only on simple tasks (i.e. push a block onto a button) with simple rules (i.e. ice blocks slide until they hit something) that are easy to understand but take careful planning to execute.  Puzzles squeeze every bit of use out of all the items and mechanics presented; rarely will a player encounter the same type of puzzle twice, keeping the game fresh and interesting.  However, a warning:  while the game does give vague hints, some of the more complex item mechanics are never explicitly explained, occasionally leading to seemingly impossible tasks until trial and error leads to a eureka moment.  Fortunately, the worst of these are confined to the Master Dungeon, an optional end-game challenge for people who LIKE impossible tasks.

If any nitpick could be made of the game, it would be that the enemies just feel sort of “there”; a necessary construct of the game’s Legend of Zelda roots, but ultimately little more than an annoyance that detract from the puzzle-solving focus of the game.  Common baddies move slowly, deal low damage, and are easily dispatched, while the three item dungeon bosses are largely uninspired, requiring simple puzzles to be solved while dodging their predictable attacks.  The final boss fortunately bucks this trend and is a frantic and satisfying exclamation point to the game.

30084380.review:
与常见RPG不同，本作的大地图BGM（[url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ty3s-151xCs]Overworld[/url]）是各主区域间四个变奏版本的衔接式播放，也就是说，切换区域时不会替换BGM，而是在维持主旋律连续播放的同时，连贯变化其和音部分。

这一亮点似乎较少被提及。让我来提一下吧。我并非音乐专业，也不是游戏设计专业，只是感觉这点值得一提。
如果有误，还望指正。

有听过将这种音乐模式称为 “动态式”（dynamic），即是：音乐内容由玩家的即时行为决定，而非以固有模式播放既定旋律段。

《马里奥赛车8》是利用多音轨做到的这种效果。我不确定本作具体是利用多音轨，还是多个单音轨的无缝接合做成的效果——反正最后的效果很棒，做出了 “精而不多” 的精致美感。

P.S. 印象中有款相对 “中古” 的、玩法与[url=http://store.steampowered.com/app/292910/]《Deponia》[/url]相似的AVG，也是以 “动态式BGM” 而闻名与留名，但我忘它叫什么了……知道的朋友还请告诉……

29995926.review: You can tell that this is a game heavily inspired by the original Legend of Zelda and Link to the Past, but this game definitely has its own charm. Whereas the mandatory dungeons are of ranging difficulty levels and generally are neither too easy nor too difficult, the random caves you can collect cards from offer a higher degree of difficulty which is refreshing. I love that instead of being a silent character, Ittle has humorous insights and conversations with her equivalent to Link's Navi: Tippsie. It's also quite nice to see that the main character is female without it being an important feature or something that is overly emphasized to please a feminist audience, it's just a character that happens to be female who slays monsters and goes on adventures. Cool. Also, Tippsie offers advice when you want it rather than nagging you, which is a small but important detail. The music is great and suits the different environments in the game, and the graphics have a fun cartoon feel to them without making the game feel immature. Love it!

29889754.review:
Preface: Be advised that this is not a "Zelda clone", but it does fall into the "puzzle dungeon" genre. It leans heavily into complex single-room puzzles with minimal combat. Contrast this with: Zelda's simpler, but multi-room puzzles, with casual-but-competent combat; and Darksiders' more refined combat and more focus on platforming.

Novel and fresh take on an abused and neglected genre.
Some highlights of particularly strong game design:
* Each puzzle feels fresh. Particularly impressive given the amount of them
* Comedic elements are light and witty, without trying to steal focus from the experience
* Difficulty curve is smooth, with a good pacing of optional mini-puzzles along a parallel difficulty curve
* At end of game, meaningful replay value in the form of multiple "low %" completion routes are made clear to the player
* Optional end-dungeon "Master Cave" adds a new level of complexity to the fundamentals
* Game intentionally avoids putting rewards in places that can be missed
* No meaningful padding or filler, all content is quickly reachable from the center of the world
* Death (though an extremely rare occurence as hazards are not the focus of the game) is not punishing, and just throws the player back at the start of the current room with minimal delay
* I'll say it: better puzzle and dungeon design than any Zelda game. Puzzle elements are clearly identifiable, and multi-room puzzles are EXTREMELY rare (and when present, are simply that a room transition is one-way, which is always reasonably obvious)

Some nitpicks to improve on:
* Zelda Link to the Past has a superior melee attack, in that it hits in a wide arc. Ittle Dew's feels clunky in comparison. Thankfully, combat is not a focus for the vast majority of the game. But...
* Final boss has a very "twitch action-game" phase when compared to the rest of the game, and thus unfairly gates players to completion by requiring a skillset they didn't sign up for, and the game didn't ramp them up to
* "Master Cave" boss is devoid of puzzle elements entirely, and REALLY feels out of place in the game as a result

I would consider this game to be mandatory reference material for all developers in the "puzzle dungeon" genre.

29723476.review:
[h1]인디계 명품 퍼즐 게임[/h1]

기본 줄거리는 빈약하다. 엔딩을 보기까지 시간도 얼마 걸리지 않는다. 그러나 이 게임은 단순히 엔딩을 보는 게임이 아니다. 이틀 듀의 매력은 바로 [b]'어떻게 엔딩을 보는가'[/b]이다.

이틀 듀는 하나부터 열까지 [b]퍼즐[/b]게임이다. 퍼즐을 푸는 도구는 3가지가 등장하는데, 재밌게도 내가 가지고 있는 아이템에 따라 퍼즐의 해법이 달라진다. 그래서 모든 도구를 모은 채 비교적 편하게 퍼즐을 풀며 엔딩을 보러 갈 수도 있고, 아이템 일부만 가진 채 엔딩으로 향할 수도 있다. 이는 도전과제에도 반영이 되어 있는데, 총 4가지의 조합 중 어떤 조합으로 엔딩을 보는가에 따라 각기 다른 도전과제를 달성할 수 있다. 하지만 도전과제를 얻기 위해 같은 스토리를 단순히 여러 번 반복해야 하는 다른 게임과 달리, 이틀 듀는 각 도구 조합마다 퍼즐의 풀잇법이 바뀌며 엔딩까지의 루트도 달라진다.

퍼즐을 풀어야 획득할 수 있는 수집품들, 더 깊은 생각이 필요한 전문가용 길, 그리고 진정한 게이머를 위한 달인의 동굴까지. 그야말로 퍼즐 보따리가 따로 없다. 퍼즐 게임을 싫어한다면 그냥 이 게임을 사면 안 된다. 하지만 퍼즐 마니아라면? 도전과제 100%를 목표로 모든 컨텐츠를 천천히 음미하길 추천한다.

I've had this game sitting on my wishlist for quite awhile, but I got overspendy with steam-sale-madness and this was part of my purchase tornado. I am SO GLAD I ended up finally buying Itlle Dew! If you've considered buying this game, please buy it- especially if you derive any joy at all from the legend of zelda series. Buy now! Its da bes.

28115774.review:
Since I wrote a negative review for Ittle Dew 2, I feel inclined to add a positive review for this game.

This game is clever, funny, challenging, endearing, and ... the list could go on and on. It's well worth the cost.

It is a puzzle game, so the puzzles and tools to solve them are incredibly important to the games success. The puzzles difficulty progresses pretty well through the game. When I hit a puzzle that took me hours to figure out, when I finally did finish, I usually felt pretty satisfied, as opposed to some puzzle games where you feel cheated (Or that the solution was unfair/obtuse for some reason). It's pretty clear when you can't do a puzzle, so you know to come back to it later. The shortcuts from if you already have other items felt very fair and that they were just a bonus for having already done other dungeons first.

The dialog is great. It very often made me laugh, some of those times quite loudly.

So yes, I would definitely recommend this game full heartedly.

27906334.review:
[b]I whole-heartedly recommend Ittle Dew. I have played it several times and I intend to come back to it more. It is well worth what you pay for it.[/b]

Ittle Dew is a single-player game which at first glance is very similar to the old NES and SNES Zelda games. That is accurate, but there is a lot more to it.

If you play for even a small amount of time, you will notice that Ittle Dew has a great irreverent style of humor which is enhanced by the lovable characters, and the mix of puzzle and combat gameplay suits it perfectly. There is very little fluff - by which I mean you will use the same puzzle elements over again, but in increasingly clever and novel ways. It is clear that the developers (Ludosity) took great care in crafting their game and distilling it down to a small, but densely packed experience that conveys constant quality.

There are five boss fights in the game, of which three, including the final boss, are required to beat the main story. A fourth is required to gain all of the items. Each of the three dungeon bosses have specific mechanics which require you to use your new dungeon item as you have learned in the preceding area, creating a diverse experience that never gets tedious. There is also a fifth (tough) boss that is completely optional.

Aside from the main story, there is an optional 'Master Cave' with twelve puzzles. They begin slightly more difficult than what you have done to beat the main story, but the difficulty ramps up quickly and some will leave you thinking for a long time before you can beat them. I was amazed at how clever some of the solutions were.

[i]If you haven't already, I recommend watching the trailer on the Steam Page - it will show you a good sample of the humor and puzzles you can expect.[/i]

__

The game also has a sequel, Ittle Dew 2. It's bigger and more combat-oriented, but it has a lot of what made this one great! I recommend both games.

http://store.steampowered.com/app/395620/Ittle_Dew_2/

27897005.review: A fantastic little game that plays very much like 2D entries in the Legend of Zelda series. The puzzles are crafted to let players figure out multiple paths throough depending on the items in their inventory.  Well worth the time if you enjoy this kind of game.

26952985.review:
[h1] Playtime and Time/money [/h1]
10-20 hours of play which is about $1/hour or 50 cents an hour. it's not that great but it is only 10$ for an excellent game.

[h1] Exactly what is this game? [/h1]
[b] The Good: [/b]
This is my favorite hidden gem game ever, it has an amazing artstyle, a cast of cute characters, a difficult puzzle style for people to enjoy and a fun atmosphere to the game in general. It has many different ways to play the game, you could skip over getting x item if you just are using your resources right etc. it's honestly just a whole load of fun.

[b] The Bad: [/b]
It's a somewhat short game, but theres a lot you can do in the game so it should still be considered fine. Ittle dew 2 improves on this by adding several more dungeons. (and I assume, ways to play the game)

[h1]So now the standard game rating:[/h1][list]
[*][b]Story: 9/10[/b] (it's silly, it's fun, it's the kind of story that doesnt take it'self too seriously and in general just a lighthearted approach, that said it doesnt have some deep engaging story to it so I can't give it some sort of perfect score comparing it to something like transistor.)
[*][b]Gameplay: 10/10 + 🎮 + 📱[/b] (Very smooth, very fun to master and I'd suggest using a controller, as it is an option and to me just feels right for this game.) (just so you know they also have this game as an app for smartphones, so if you feel like it you could check it out on that platform - it plays fine everywhere)
[*][b]Presentation: 10/10[/b] (I'm absolutely in love with the art style that this game has, and I enjoy how all the main enemies are creative and fun and very jenny. you'll grow to love certain characters in ludosity's universe of games and you'll want to play some of their other games.)
[*][b]Soundtrack: 10/10[/b] (It's honestly just good fitting music thats also memorable, and didn't get old. I loved it.)
[*][b]Replayability: 9/10[/b] (Theres a certain point where you cannot do the game a different way, but thats an achievement on it's own to play the game out. I've seen people speed running this game, and I've seen people try taking really odd routes that seemed like fun overall, if you want to play it more you can, for a very long time.)

非常棒的一款游戏，游戏氛围轻松诙谐，不乏一些有趣的调侃，在这样的游戏氛围下，解密要素却一点都不含糊，因为是低价购买，本以为会是一款喜加一，但是一周目剧情通了之后仍然回味无穷。

26620850.review:
Juego de puzzles y aventura.

26475237.review:
[i]Ittle Dew[/i] is a game which made me realize that the Zelda-like genre of games is inherently awful and that people who like them probably only like them out of nostalgia. It claims to "boil down the classic adventure formula until there is only fun left" but I've realized no amount of boiling will get rid of the BS that goes straight to the very bones of this game and games in similar veins. I understand that there is a level of subjectivity involved, that maybe this genre is just not "for me," but this is my review based on my experience of the game, most of which is negative. 

Mechanically, nearly everything about this game is bad. It does not modernize or simplify ("boil down" to use the devs' words) any of the frustrations of old school Zelda, it literally rips the most infuriating aspects of those games out and reskins them. It manages to even add some of its own terrible ideas to the pile of garbage. I don't usually do this but I listed them down.

1) Your weapon attack has no arc at all. You literally cannot damage something that is right next to you but diagonal despite  the sword having a visual arc and enemies being able to knock into you and kill you like every game. This isn't Final Fantasy Tactics, I don't understand what the problem is.
2) The hearts mechanic. It's so pointless to make your HP into collectibles, I don't understand why you would even bother when there's nothing to gain from killing enemies that aren't linked to puzzles. You're more likely to lose hearts than gain them given how your attacks are bound to the four cardinal directions whilst enemies fill the rooms and spam them with projectiles and fast moving bodies. Then when you die, you just gain back all your hearts anyway. And this is a game that encourages speed running. It literally does this just to emulate Zelda, there's absolutely no mechanical reason for the game to have this archaic system.
3) Respawning enemies. Again, just run past everything because even if you kill anything it only serves as a removal of a distraction anyway.
4) Respawning enemies in puzzle rooms.  
5) Undefeatable instant kill enemies. Yup, they stole Wallmasters. The most garbage enemy in all of the Zelda franchise and you decided to emulate that.
6) UNDEFEATABLE INSTANT KILL ENEMIES IN PUZZLE ROOMS. Just go to hell and stay there, please.
7) Puzzle bosses that have to be hit more than once. It's a puzzle right? The same puzzle three times over doesn't make it more difficult, it just makes it tedious.
8) Dexterity tests. This is where I finally drew the line. I was having trouble with a puzzle in the Master Cave and finally gave in and looked up the solution and as it turned out the solution involved pushing a dozen buttons in the correct order in a very small window of time, which the game asks you for nowhere else. Someone asked about the same puzzle on the front page of the forums at the time of this review, and the devs literally reply "Sorry not sorry." Are you kidding me.

I'll give them props on two fronts: they don't make any of the collectibles missable despite having branching dungeon designs, and the worst parts of the game are optional. In fact, a lot of the game seems to be optional. Kind of makes me think they were aware that people would want to skip playing most of it.

I'm being mean. This is probably a really good game for the genre, definitely compared to most of Steam. I also genuinely love the art style. But as I said at the start, I realized that this genre as a whole is just bad, the aspects of it that are considered its trademarks add nothing but artificial difficulties to a game which doesn't have a strong core of anything. If it's about the puzzles, why have all the enemies distracting you from them? If it's about beating things up or performing pro gamer moves, why are the mechanics all so wanky? It can't be about story, there's no story barring some snarky jabs at its predecessors.

Games of this breed of "action-adventure", a kind of mix and match of everything, belong to another time period. Having a modern version just highlights how badly the ideas have aged with time and how the genre doesn't hold up without quality of living adjustments that other games have evolved over time. So the thing that I gained the most out of playing this game is an acute awareness that I don't actually like games like this.

25833120.review:
This may look like a Zelda clone (and it is), but it is so much more than that. Sure, you have the usual mechanics of hacking and slashing monsters of increasing difficulty, you have powerups that let you solve harder puzzles, you have dungeons with bosses that are defeated by your most recent powerup, you have even the same kind of 2-D world, even down to the platforms and bridges. You've even got the same sliding of boxes to unlock doors and using bombs to unlock hidden passageways. But does Link get to MAKE his own boxes? Does he get to warp around within a single room of a dungeon? No, but Ittle Dew does (I think that's her name. Otherwise the title makes absolutely no sense and is completely arbitrary).

The main difference between this and Zelda is that there is much more block moving, as this is the main mechanic. You have four main powerups (fiery sword to light things on fire and break ice, portal blocks that act as weights, portal wand that targets things and sends them through where your portals are, and an ice wand that freezes blocks for easy pushing and douses flames.) The puzzles are based on combining all of these weapons to traverse a very Zelda-like dungeon. The difficulty increases as they put you in rooms that are supposed to be solvable but without explaining additional things that you can do with the powerups. (e.g. if you shoot ice on a wall, it makes it reflective, which means you can zap yourself with the portal gun. Took me a loooooong time to figure that out, and it was by accident.)

Ittle Dew also has some good meta-humor. It knows it's a Zelda clone, and has fun with it by poking at the various tropes along the way. For example, enemies drop hearts, which replenish your health, but they're actually fleshy hearts that flop to the ground with a sickening squelch, and the character actually eats them like an apple. There's a sidekick animal that is called Tippsie that always looks drunk on whine (though, you can see it's actually health potions).

It's not very long, so don't expect Zelda length playtime. Mine was a few hours, mostly because I spent a long time experimenting in just a few dungeons that were giving me trouble for dozens of minutes, whereas the average dungeon took about 2 minutes. The final boss is also a doozy, but mostly because there are 7 stages and it's not clear what you have to do. Fortunately, there are checkpoints after every stage for the boss, and in normal levels, you just go back to the nearest door (not the entrance to the dungeon, as in Zelda, a plus for Ittle Dew!)

Overall, I enjoyed it. Probably won't play it again, although there are "Professional shortcuts" scattered all around for repeat players who already know some of the advanced move combinations and want to speedrun through. I think for under $5 it's worth it. I got it in a Humble Bundle with, like, six other games, so I definitely got my money's worth in that case. Buy it on sale, especially if you like puzzle games or Zelda.

23932097.review:
Ittle Dew is not only a clever name, but a very clever game. It takes Zelda's block pushing, torch lighting, and enemy managing puzzles to a point where they actually take some thought. The main game can take as long or little as you want; it took me about six hours to explore the entire castle and collect most of the cards, but the game can be completed in under 15 minutes (thank you, achievements, for pointing that out). 

Furthermore, you technically only need two of the game's three items to complete the game, a feat accomplished by clever level design, multiple routes, and puzzles with multiple solutions. Each item is functionally very different from the others, so puzzles that are easy when you have the teleport wand may be really challenging without it.

There are also two levels in the world that only exist to offer more challenging puzzles to those that want them. I found them to be really enjoyable, but I'm happy that they are optional.

The game's art is simple yet clear, and it gives the game's characters plenty of personality. The dialogue is witty and occasionally pokes fun at game tropes, though I wish there was an option to disable the dialogue for future playthroughs.

I was willing to give a neutral rating for all of the above reasons until the final boss. The final boss reminded me step-by-step of why exactly I HATED this game.

22570582.review:
I give this game a very cautious recommendation.

I picked it up because I'm a huge Zelda fan, and it was on sale at the time. The gameplay is similar to a 2D Zelda in many regards in that you explore, fight, and solve puzzles using your trusty stick/sword and items that you gain throughout your adventure. So yes, there are a lot of familiar elements here if you like these kinds of games.

That said, it doesn't PLAY like a Zelda game. That's not necessarily a bad thing depending on why you enjoy these games in the first place. Whereas Zelda has very tight, simple combat and excellent monster design, it becomes apparent soon after starting this game that combat is not the main focus. Ittle's stick has a short range and some enemies do not suffer knockback when hit. There are also not many enemies with unique weaknesses. Most of them are a simple hack n' slash affair.

Where this game truly shines is in the puzzle department. I would even say that this game is more of a puzzle game than a 2D adventure game, because the world is compact and filled to the brim with puzzles. Many of them are actually challenging! I literally spent hours in the Master Cave, an optional dungeon filled with the toughest puzzles that this game has to offer, because the puzzles were so difficult and I was determined to solve them without a guide. Though I felt like ripping my hair out at the time, solving these complex puzzles was a rewarding experience in and of itself, unlike in Zelda dungeons where it sometimes feels like puzzles are just there to pad the game out.

This is a short game, and there are only three items (besides the default stick) that you can obtain. The twist is that these items work together to help you solve puzzles and traverse the main dungeon. For instance, you can combine the portal wand and the ice rod to create an ice block that warps you to the other side of the room. This part of the game was handled ingeniously. There are so many things you can do with these three items and the objects in your environment. There are also multiple ways that you can beat the game, and you don't even need all of the items to do it. Pretty cool!

As mentioned, this game is short. If you skipped the Master Cave, it would likely take you about 3-5 hours on your first attempt. The replay value comes from finding out different ways to beat the game using different combinations of items. The game is also uniformly hilarious and aware of its genre. Even the credit sequence is funny.

TL;DR - This is more of a puzzle game than a 2D adventure game. If you like puzzles, you will probably like it.

This game is much more a puzzle game than an adventure game. It consists of 
80% block pushing puzzle solving with some of the hardest puzzles I ever faced and I faced lots. In fact the puzzles remembered me of the ones in Goof Troop. I often thought "How can this even be possible?". At least the [spoiler]Master-Cave[/spoiler] will get you to really hard thinking.
10% being like Zelda and
10% making fun of Zelda ^^ (I love Zelda and laughed heartily, because it nails it)

The puzzles have some cool and innovative mechanics. [spoiler]You can summon a portal block, then shoot a portal projectile which will teleport certain things to where the portal block stands. You can freeze walls to mirror portal projectiles or freeze ignited bombs to stop them from exploding a short time until they dew.[/spoiler] This I suppose gives the game not only its name: It will dew = It'll dew = Ittle Dew, but gives many possibilities for the puzzles. And these possibilities are used with skilled cunning by the devs *GREAT PRAISE*.

Suggested for pushing puzzle logic likers ;-)

21641275.review:
There are certain qualities that make a game good.  Good controls, or combat system.  Maybe a fun unlock/leveling system, or a great storyline that sucks you in.  While I can't say Ittle Dew is exemplary by any means (specifically, the ones previously listed) it excels well in understanding its unique charm.  The flaws, in this sense, actually improve the game (subjectively, of course) since the whole game is just filled with character.

The Zelda-esque gameplay has been done a hundred times, so you should know the exact gameplay you're getting into--As a side note, it is pretty unique in that its short, but certain items (which all help solve the game's puzzles) can be collected in different orders on your playthroughs, though I admit I've only played through the main game once.

My favorite part of this game though was the dialogues--Its very rare in a game do I get excited to drop the controller and see some back  and forths, complete with animated character portraits, that, once again, are filled to the brim with developer charm.

The world is colorful and the characters in it are what I'd consider the game's top aspect. With that said, the $10 price might be high, but at $5 or less you shouldn't pass up on playing this game at least once.

재미있습니다.
주인공인 ittle(Little 이 아닙니다)과 약물중독 개요정이 땟목위에서 낮잠을 자며 시작합니다. 뗏목의 체력이 1/3500이었는지 돌에 톡 '닿은' 뒤 쾅 하며 산산조각이 나고 어느 섬에 닿으며 이야기가 시작됩니다. 장르는 RPG를 한 숟가락 섞은 퍼즐게임입니다. 오랜만에 RPG나 해볼까 하며 시작했지만 첫 번째 동굴을 지나며 뭔가 이상함을 느꼈습니다. 퍼즐의 난이도는 높진 않으며 약간만 생각한다면 바로 풀어낼 수 있습니다. 하지만 여타 퍼즐처럼 '클리어는 쉽지만 100% 클리어는 어렵다' 라는 특성을 가지고 있죠. 뭐든 100% 뽑지 않으면 성에 차지 않는 성격이지만 참았습니다. 클리어까지는 3시간 걸렸습니다만 100%클리어까진 꽤 오랜 시간을 들여야 할 것 같습니다.
굳이 단점을 뽑자면 초반 목검류의 공격 판정이 매우 애매한 점을 꼽을 수 있습니다. 공격사거리는 매우 짧으며 적은 그에 비해 빠르고 무작위 움직임을 보이기 때문에 공격하는데 실패한다면 바로 도망가셔야 합니다. 괜히 객기 부리시다가 카운터 어택에 피가 까입니다. 넉백도 거의 없어 2회 연속공격을 시도하다간 쳐맞기 십상입니다. 말로 설명을 할 수가 없네요. 직접 쳐맞아보시길 바랍니다. 하지만 적을 찢으면 회복아이템이 자주 나오기 때문에 피격후 무적 상태를 이용해 적을 죽인 후 금방 만땅이 될 수 있습니다.
간간히 유머가 들어있어 재미나게 읽으며 플레이했습니다. 잘 만든 인디게임이란 느낌이 들었습니다. 주인공과 개요정도 참 귀엽습니다. 한 가지 스포일러를 하자면, [spoiler]주인공과 개요정은 여자입니다.[/spoiler]

21188766.review:
Playing through this game was quite relaxing. It's a short game that you can finish in a 'less than 3 hours session'. You mainly progress via completing puzzles and opening doors. The game is really user-friendly: it is filled with tips everywhere. There are enemies to fight but the gameplay is mostly centered around puzzles. The bosses are all cool to fight though. There is a bit of a story too but it's nothing really crazy, it is funny sometimes.

Even if the game is short, it has replayability value. Like every dungeons you go has secret paths. You have to complete puzzles to get through those too. They can be pretty hard sometimes. The point of those paths is to speedup your playthrough. I think it's cool that a big part of the game was built around speedrunning it. There is a steam achievement for completing it under 15 minutes. If you want more challenge the game offers it too: 2 optional zones with hard stuff in it.

You liked the Zelda games? Like puzzles? Like cute games? Want to laugh a bit? Well get you your wallet and start to play as this pretty female protagonist named Ittle Dew :)

7/10

20971667.review:
tldr : Si vous aimez les puzzles/enigmes et les univers louffoques et colorés  : C'est vachement bien, prenez le !

Excellent Puzzle game coloré, plein d'humour et de charme !

Le jeu propose de résoudre des séries de puzzles, intégrés dans un univers d'aventurier typique (chateau, dongeon, cave, crypte, boss ...), et bardés de créatures loufoques, grâce à trois items récupérés au fil de l'aventure. Tout est parfaitement accessible, entièrement logique, et rare sont les puzzles qui demandent en plus des réflexes (Je ne suis pas accros aux puzzles qui demandent du timing). Par contre certains vous donneront certainement du fil a retordre, et quel plaisir de trouver seul, grâce à son petit cerveau, comment avancer ! :)

A l'heure de cette review, sur plus de 100 jeux dans ma collection, il n'y en a que deux qui m'ont donnés envie de completer tous les achievements steam : Legend of Grimrock, et celui ci.

Pourquoi ?

Parce qu'au dela des achievements faciles et humoristiques, certains prolongent la vie du jeu en donnant un nouveau sens à l'aventure.
Notamment en demandant de rejouer l'aventure avec seulement deux des trois items (3 achievement differents, pour chacune des combinaisons), et donc de réfléchir completement differement. Un autre demande de ne tuer aucune créature d'un certain type, hors, c'est parfois obligatoire pour passer certains puzzle ! Ben, c'est pas grave, on va trouver une autre façon de faire ....

... et réaliser que le design des puzzles et des levels est simplement brillant.

Bref, un vrai coup de coeur !

20435953.review:
Fun Zelda-esque Puzzle Adventure Game

This is NOT an RPG. It's a cute adventure game focused strictly on solving puzzles. You solve one, open the door, move to the next room and so on. The only few rpg elements include things like health upgrades and cash to buy items (3 items that open up more puzzle mechanics).


PROS
- Lovely art style and animation, very fitting.
- The writing is really fun. Expect lots of snarky comments and quirky dialogues.
- The base game is challenging enough for casual playthroughs. There's an optional "dungeon" full of super hard puzzles for the aditional challenge
- 60fps goodness, runs so smooth

CONS
- All the puzzles in game revolve around box pushing mechanics. Provides a good challenge but could get boring after a while.
- Lack of exploration
- I wish the characters had more story or progression, loved all of them.
- Not much replayability unless you want the achievements, most of which are rerunning the game with some sort of handicap.
- The game is short (my first blind playthrough was 2:30 hours, got all collectables and completed the extra hard dungeon too)

SUM
If you like puzzlers and don't mind lots of box pushing, you'll love it. The humour is great and the game is very pretty to look at. The puzzles can get extremely difficult (even convoluted) and provide a great challenge. If you're into speedrunning the game's got that too.

20017260.review:
Holy shit I have somehow not written a review for Ittle Dew yet.

To call Ittle Dew a Zeldalike is to do it a disservice. While the inspiration is clear, Ittle Dew focuses almost completely on the puzzle aspects, and completely outdoes Zelda in this regard. In the game, there are only three items. One item burns things, one item freezes things, and one item moves things. All of these items interact with each other, and create interesting puzzles as a result. The game is beatable with all three items, or with any two. The items can be acquired in any order. This actually dramatically changes the way you'll progress through the game, as well as the puzzles you will encounter. There is also a sort of modular difficulty, in that many puzzles are solvable with only one or two of the items, but are difficult. If you come back more fully equipped, it usually makes the puzzles much easier.

That's all I have to say mechanically, which I think is the primary draw of the game. However, it also oozes charm. It uses a Home Movies-esque Squigglevision style animation which lets you immediately understand what is interactable on the screen. It has a lot of cute dialogue. The characters are one-note, but they do what they need to, and have some pretty funny jokes involved with them.

I think this is easily in my top 10 games. Everyone who has an appreciation for tight design should play it.

19962654.review:
这是一个曾经给了我极大影响的游戏，强烈推荐。赶上圣诞打折，入了正版，很多谜题的解法已经记不清楚了，仍然玩得开心如初见。
简单的操作，简单的谜题器件，但是却排列组合出千姿百态丰富多彩的谜题，和其他那些只不断增加复杂的操作或者复杂的器件来增加表面上的复杂度，结果却导致大部分东西都大同小异的二三流解谜游戏设计形成鲜明对比，对作者的谜题设计能力十分钦佩。有许多在同一地图上的谜题，用不同的道具有不同的解法，第一周目时体会不到，到了第二、第三周目甚至更多的周目，才会发现每一个谜题在设计上的精妙和复杂。而且最最难得的是，作者很友好地控制了谜题的难度，全程三道具主线其实并没有会让人卡关很久的谜题，都是只需要稍微思考就可以解出的谜题，之后作者把高难度的谜题都放在了大师洞和其他双道具路线里（尤其是传送+冰的路线，最后的谜题大师洞级别），供高级向的玩家们去自虐。林林总总，都能看出作者在此游戏的关卡设计上是用了极其大的心思的，将普通玩家与高级玩家有效分离，使大家都能享受到游戏的乐趣，并且提供了一个合理的阶梯能使普通玩家逐渐进阶成高级玩家，可谓是十分聪明和精巧，有别于其他大部分难度毫无阶梯性规律性设计性而言的那些很随性的解谜游戏。
画面是这种看上去有些糙的粗线条手绘画风，但是实际上通了大师洞拿到了游戏gallery，才发现作者在此版本之前还有两个版本：象素风和精致手绘风，但是这两版的画面最后都被废弃掉，而换用了这种粗线条风格，应该是有意为之，确实此画风相比其他两种更适合此游戏的基调（虽然可能乍看上去逼格不如另两种），居然能大刀阔斧地革掉两个画面相当不错的版本，可见作者在制作游戏的过程中精益求精的程度。
此游戏的引擎是unity3d，而且还是很古旧的版本，但是却可以说是基本毫无“Unity3d痕迹”，一般u3d游戏的什么闪退、卡顿、读取未响应、内存爆炸、bug满天飞之类的常见毛病在此游戏中是没有的，作者对做游戏的认真态度可见一斑。
ittle dew2那个大坑不知何年何月才会平，好久都没有听到新消息了，按这种作者精益求精的态度搞下去，估计还要好久。十分期待2代上架的那一天。

Un juego de puzzles de tratamiento impecable. Los puzzles tienen varias soluciones y la posibilidad que ofrece el juego de pasarselo con cualquier combinación de 2 items (de los 3 que ofrece) hace que el jugador sienta que puede decidir su propio camino evitando así la linealidad de muchos otros.

Las mazmorras de un solo item recuerdan a un diseño de niveles por item como el de Zelda (aunque compararlos sería odioso, ambos tienen sus puntos fuertes y puntos flojos), y están pensados a la perfección.

Un juego de sobresaliente, dificil en los juegos de hoy día.

Puntuaciones personales:
Jugabilidad 5/5
Gráficos 5/5
Sonido 5/5
Dificultad 3/5

A favor:
-Ambientación.
-Humor.
-Los controles responden como tu quieres.
-Te hace pensar.
-Te lo puedes pasar en 15 minutos.
-Un personaje femenino de verdad y no una muñeca prefabricada que lo único que desea es vender.
-The Master Cave.

En contra:
-En su versión larga (completandolo entero), quizás se echa de menos algún puzzle más complejo en cuanto al planteamiento, aunque los puzzles de habilidad de dificultad alta son bastante buenos.
-Que no haya salido la segunda parte.

Top kek for needing my DOB to view the store page.  What the actual hell...

+engaging zeldaesque block puzzler.
+doesn't take itself too seriously.
+puzzles aren't impossible but will haunt you if you quit w/o finishing them.  It's a different genre but I'd put them about on par w/ the Swapper or Vessel.
+despite big picture saying otherwise, its the BEST game I own to play from the sofa.  My vision isn't great and this game makes for EXCELLENT play from the sofa.  The print is huge, everything is bright and well-defined and cartoony.

-the flow of the game feels weird.  It's hard to explain but the area's connect strangely and they force you in and out of the action without any forwarning or causation.  That's my only complaint but it's a big one.  It's not a deal breaker, but once you play the game you'll see what I mean;  everything about it seems kind of jerky and half-baked.  It's like if they had more time or a bigger budget they could make an A title, but as it stands, to be generous, Ittle Dew is a B-; it's like a very well made flash game from a decade ago. 19138162.review:
Ittle Dew is a simple top-down action adventure game about an adventurer, Ittle Dew, and her magical fox companion, Tippsie. The duo crashes their raft against an island with a castle, and they do as adventurers do. They explore that shit hard.

Ittle Dew was a lot of fun, despite its very short length. It has the look and feel of a Zelda clone, but it leans a bit harder into the puzzles than Zelda games tend to. That's definitely a good thing, considering how interesting the puzzles can be. You use a small set of three items to solve a decent variety of puzzles ranging from incredibly easy to fairly difficult. I doubt you'll be pulling your hair out with many of them. 

It was smart for Ittle Dew to focus more on puzzles than combat, because the hit detection is sloppy with a capital S. You'll often find your sword passing through enemies while you often get hit from incredibly awkward angles. On top of that, later rooms can be filled with projectile launching enemies. Thankfully, the only consequence for death is a room restart, so it never gets to be too frustrating.

I spent just over 2 hours in my playthrough of Ittle Dew (2 hours, 1 minute, 5 seconds according to the in game timer). A 100% completion run could easily see 1-2 more hours added onto that. While this is definitely short, it's certainly a very enjoyable experience. Ittle Dew's leaderboards also challenge you to compete with others in speedruns of a few different categories. 

All that said, $10 may seem to be a fair price, or it may seem to be a bit too much. If you really enjoy 2D Zelda games and their imitators, and if you really enjoy speedruns and replaying games, grab this one at full price. If any of those three previous qualifiers don't apply to you, but you still want to check this one out, maybe wait for a sale.

For those who like score numbers, I'll take the score straight from Ittle Dew's mouth. It's a 3/5 at best.

19133086.review:
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Spiel: 

Ein klassische Action-Adventure mit viel Humor, Charme und nur Kistenrätseln.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Einzelspieler:

Man spielt die Heldin Ittle Dew, die auf einer Insel gestrandet ist und gerne wieder davon weg möchte. Aber um dies zu schaffen muss sie dem Händler Itan der Ihr ein Floss bauen will eine Item bringen um an das Item heran zu kommen muss sie 3 Dungeons und eine Hauptdungeon schaffen. Die Dungeons sind wie alles in dem Spiel alle recht klein gehalten aber dennoch schön gemacht. Die Waffen sind nur wenige aber immer so dass sie vielseitig einsetzbar sind im verschieden Gegner auf verschiedene Weis zu töten. Die Waffen werden auch zum Lösen der vielen schiebe Rätsel benötigt die auf der ganzen Karte und Tempeln verstreut sind. Leider gibt es für die Rätsel die man nebenbei löst nie etwas Wichtiges für den Spielablauf, meistens nur Sammelkarten oder ab und an etwas um ein neues Herz für seine Energie leiste zu bekommen. 

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Grafik:

Die Grafik ist sehr gut, gibt’s nichts zu mekkern.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Musik:

Die Musik ist auch Super passt einfach zum ganzen Spiel..

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Steuerung:

Die Steuerung ist mit dem Gamepad einfach klasse. 

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Pro/Contra:

+ deutsche Übersetzung
+ viele Witz und Humor
+ schwere Rätsel
- manchmal Rätsel zu schwer ^^
- nur Schiebe Rätsel
- etwas zu kurz

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Fazit:

Ittle Dew ist meiner Meinung nach KEIN ZELDA, dafür ist es einfach zu wenig an Tiefgang und Abwechslung. Die Geschichte ist einfach und zweckmäßig gehalten, aber die Dialoge von den Figuren sind wirklich SUPER. Wer Zelda gespielt hat wird hier öfter mal lachen, da viele kleine Anspielungen zu finden sind. Wer auf Schieberätsel ala Zelda steht wird hier nicht zu kurz kommen, wer Schieberätsel schon bei Zelda nicht möchte sollte wohl eher die Finger von lassen. Ich hatte für kurze Zeit meinen Spass, und werde sicherlich auch den zweiten Teil spielen. Wer also es mal im Angebot sieht kann sicherlich als Action-Adventure Fan bedenkenlos zugreifen.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Zusammengefasst: 

Einzelspieler: 7/10
Grafik: 10/10
Musik: 10/10
Steuerung: 10/10
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Spiel: 9/10

18425716.review:
[b]首先，感謝Nick.exe大大前陣子製作的中文翻譯！翻譯品質很好，讓玩家能體會到劇情有趣之處。
想找Nick大的中文翻譯請自行google搜尋「《Ittle Dew 小不點尋寶記》正體中文模組」[/b]

[h1] 這是一款簡單卻又不簡單的小品解謎遊戲！[/h1]
[b]看似小品卻耐人尋味~[/b]

無論從哪方面來看，這款都在幽默地致敬與吐槽《薩爾達傳說》系列。
片頭一開始主角漂流到一座未知小島，有種薩爾達《夢見島》的既視感。
然後主角身旁跟著一隻「會飛的狐狸」(?)，致敬薩爾達中負責給主角提示的"妖精"。
遊戲整體畫面風格、介面設計也都十分薩爾達。

遊戲劇情十分無俚頭，時常把解謎類型的特色拿來吐槽，想當有趣!
遊戲目的也很單純，主要就是在一座大城堡中沿途破解小關卡，最後抵達關鍵寶物的所在地。

遊戲解謎基本上就只有一種「倉庫番」（推箱子）類型。
主角只有最多三種功能道具，加上少量場景互動物件，例如磚塊、炸彈、怪物。
然而千萬別小看這看似簡單的推箱子，這些少數條件卻能互相融合，設計出數十種難度各異的謎題。
主線謎題基本上不會太難，然而遊戲最終隱藏試煉-「大師洞穴」的難度等級根本天差地遠!
個人解到一半時曾有幾乎想放棄與偷看攻略的衝動XD

此外這款遊戲最大的樂趣，就是謎題解法不只一種，而即使道具沒有拿齊全也有另一套解法全破遊戲。
玩家可以自我挑戰，嘗試用另一種角度來解題，這讓遊戲具有重複破關的價值。

《優點》：
●手繪風格的畫面清新舒適，角色設計有特色、很可愛。
●劇情相當逗趣、無俚頭，對話與吐槽讓人會心一笑。
●解謎簡單上手但有深度，讓玩家學習「多想」or「不要想太多」。
●關卡安排想當有巧思，玩家可以用不只一種方法破關，重玩度提升。遊戲系統本身其實種類很少，然而衍生出的謎題組合變化很多，並不會很快就乏味。

《缺點》：
●主線流程不長，正常玩我想大概3、4小時就能全破。
●提示君（會飛的狐狸）在BOSS戰的提示有點太明顯，不過這點算是個人吹毛求疵、無傷大雅啦。
●劇情、遊戲要素份量不多。當然我也知道這款畢竟是小品，不過還是蠻期望續作能增加份量，例如讓NPC有更多可互動的支線劇情、收集要素的種類增加。如果份量能再提升，即使定價變高一點我也覺得無妨。
●[spoiler]有青蛙娘、狐狸娘，為何沒有貓娘、兔娘? 製作組偷懶啦![/spoiler]

18352379.review:
Personal Rating: 8 of 10

If you liked puzzle game, Ittle Dew is for you. Don't be fooled by the simplistic graphics, the adventure tag or the RPG liked screen shots. Ittle Dew is a game with minimalist and nonsensicle plot with a little exploring with tonnes of puzzle.

In this game, you need to explore dungeon and progress by solving puzzles and unlocking doors. Each area may consists of 1 to several puzzles that you need to solve with the aid of certain weapons. They can be more than 1 approach to solving the puzzle. Each room is reset when you leave the area and coming back. Solving the puzzle will then unlock the doors permanently.

The puzzles can be challenging especially the optional ones. The mechanics can be simply but the logic can be tricky. If you longed for greater challenge, you can always visit the master dungeon (which is optional), but be warned as you might need to juice the brain a little.

The boss fights can be tough as there are no hint on how you should approach or tackle them. My guess is there were meant to be that way so it seems like another puzzle for you to solve along the way. 

My only beef with the game is the achievement. Personally I think there is no reason to replay them as the puzzles and maps are the same even though there are several ways to tackle them. You might already solve them during your first gameplay but having all three weapons automatically cancels the achievement.

18082110.review:
With the sequel confirmed and on the way, getting into Ittle Dew now is the perfect time. I had always meant to play this game but only now did I ever give it the chance. 

Maybe it was the Adventure Time style and humor that put me off, leading me to believe this game would be a nonsensical game without any logic. It is nosensical, in a good way, but the puzzles and gameplay are finely crafted with various solutions in an otherwise illogical adventure.

[h1] Wake up, Adventurer. [/h1]

The story for Ittle Dew is simple: Beat things up and solve puzzles. And then you have weirdo, meta characters and conversations that take slight jabs at the game itself. The interactions with Tippsie (the flying fox) and Ittle are my favorite bits in the game, mostly because of how cynical and arrogant Tippsie comes off. 

If you do like the wierdness humor of Adventure Time or Regular Show, then you'll probably find the other characters entertaining. I had one or two laughs as I liked the small world of the game, but I didn't find anything too interesting or memorable.

[h1]What Can You Dew?[/h1]

Where the story and the characters were lacking, the puzzle/adventuring aspects of the game were what sold me on the game itself. And not on my first playthrough but my third one as well.

You are given a stick to start with that can temporarily be set on fire. You later can get a Flame Scimitar (like the stick but stronger and always on fire), the Portal Wand that can create blocks and teleport things, and a Freeze Wand. Some items have some synnergy between them that becomes useful when solving a room when you only have two items.

In order to beat the game, you only require two out of three items; however, on your first playthrough, you will want to collect all three items to 100% the game. Not only would you want to do this for achievements, but after each item-boss, there are extra dungeons that teach you more in-game mechanics through smaller, harder puzzles.

The only reward  worth caring about is the heart-notes for extra lives; the cards are added in for flavor, but it's the practice of familiarizing yourself with the mechanics and experimenting with your tools are the real rewards for the challenge. They're all centered on the item you bought and they're all completely optional, so the puzzles are a great method of teaching the player how to play the game better.

Once you have all three items, and you think you're smart enough, you can then tackle the Master Cave. You might think these challenges begin fairly simple (for the first four or five rooms), but the later challenges will test your reflexes as much as your puzzle-solving skills, sometimes in really convuluted ways. 

I'll admit I had to use a guide because some solutions were so specific to the millisecond I wouldn't be able to figure it out on my own. Although the payoff for completing the twelve hardest puzzles of the game is anticlimatic (as well as the boss-fight), this part of the game will teach you skills you were not even aware of you had all the time with a given tool (or combination of the two).

A complete playthrough, on a (mostly) blind run, will take you about four to seven in-game hours depending on how stubborn you are to avoid a guide. The real fun of the game comes on your next three playthroughs.

[h1]A Task Against Familiarity[/h1]

As mentioned before, the game is designed for you to complete the game with two out of three items. Backtracking for the items is less tedious as you'll most likely be able to solve the professional shortcuts after the Master Cave. Navigating through the Castle with a limited amount of items is the real challenge.

The game forces you to tackle certain rooms for enough loot for what you need while also figuring out how to reach the final boss-room. The final boss fight is tailored to whatever items you have, although the fight is much shorter as a result. 

Unfortunately, as a result of not having enough items to do everything, your playthrough from 4 to six hours goes down to less than fifteen minutes to three hours at most as a result of handicaping yourself. 

These shorter runs are still worthwhile because the game takes previous challenges and does a new spin on them, and some rooms are probably impossible (but you wont' know until you try), so these playthroughs are not worthless. 

I just wish there was some way to still 100% ALL rooms with these limitations. No run will match the first one in length or for completion, and they freel tailored for speedrunners alone. (I'm not a fan of speedrunning my games; I prefer to take my time and relax). 

[h1]"Eh, 3 out of 5 at best."[/h1]

This isn't my score of the game, but I think that line quite sums up my thoughts. The game has great potential to expand upon, but the shortcomings on the more interesting playthroughs make me hopeful for more polish from a game that is already nicely polished.

18078907.review:
Ce jeu sent le [b]Zelda[/b] à plein nez... mais il n'en a pas la saveur ! Pas épique pour un sou, il reste [b]distrayant[/b] toutefois car ce n'est pas un vulgaire plagiat sans âme. 

Au contraire, si les développeurs assument totalement l'allègre [b]pompage[/b] qu'ils ont fait du titre de Nintendo, c'est pour mieux le [b]tourner en dérision[/b]. Exemple : à l'instar de Link, l'héroïne ramasse des coeurs pour récupérer de la santé. Sauf qu'ici, le chien-fée qui l'accompagne lui dit qu'il trouve vraiment dégôutant de manger des coeurs trouvés par terre ! "Pas grave, j'ai soufflé dessus avant" rétorque la petite ! J'ai bien adhéré à [b]l'humour[/b], à la prise de recul, ce qui est rare dans un jeu. C'est à mon avis le point fort d'Ittle Dew, et ce qui le démarque d'autres titres qui reprennent également l'éternel - et efficace - schéma de zelda : dongeons, salles d'enigmes, trésors, boss. 

A noter que l'aventure est plutôt [b]courte[/b], il est donc judicieux d'attendre une petite promo ou un bundle pour ne pas gâcher le plaisir.

17937236.review: I got this game because the trailers reminded me quite a bit of Zelda 3.  That impression proved to be largely inaccurate.  They share some superficial similarity... a tope-down perspective, a sandy haired protatgonist clad in green, some hack and slash gameplay, bombs, wands, and puzzle solving...  But Ittle Dew is much more oriented toward the puzzle solving.  The controls are quite firm-feeling, and are not well-suited to extensive swordplay, but the level design doesn't push a lot of hack'n'slash action.  Most rooms have puzzles to be solved, and the game is mostly non-linear.  In fact, it offers built in challenge modes by purchasingonly 2 of the 3 items offered for the completion of the game's puzzles, with semi-secret alternate routes to accommodate those that choose the handicap.  It also has some extra challenge rooms at the end of the game, after all the items are unlocked.  Some of these border on unfair by featuring puzzles that exploit mechanics that were never seen in the main game in ways that aren't intuitively very clear.  The main quest, by comparison, is almost too straight forward and kid-friendly in its puzzle design.  Approach it with tempered expectations and it's fun game on its own, worth spending a few hours on.
