17630466.review:
Ittle Dew is a fun, clever, and amusing gem.

The gameplay is top-down adventure stuff, the kind Zelda players will be at home with. The game is mostly puzzle based though also containes a lot of enemies to fight. But it's definitely the puzzles you'll be concerned with, since they get HARD. A few of the required puzzles are very brainbending, though for the most part quite passable.

The optional puzzles are a different story. In addition to puzzles in out-of-the-way caves for collectable rewards (Either superfluous cards or helpful bits of paper) there are "professional shortcuts" which allow you to bypass most of the game if you're smart and skilled enough to use them. You probably won't be, by the by. Shortcuts aside though, the game works quite well mechanically, and the three tools you get to solve puzzles with open up a lot of variety and give way to clever puzzles. Some puzzles were so clever I never figured them out, and I probably never will. And that's okay.

As an aside, I received my copy of the game through a promotion with Games Matter. They are cool people you spotlight games and throw free copies at people, so go ahead and follow them at @GamesMatterHQ.

17010538.review:
Ittle Dew is a game of adventure and independent puzzle.

You control Ittle Dew, a young girl without shoes, who end up on an island full of monsters. Tippsie, her loyal sidekick, will give her some hints during the adventure. The only human being of the island, who is also to the manager of the local store, proposes her an exchange: a raft to leave the island, in exchange for an artefact hidden in the castle of the island.

A real adventure for the young Ittle Dew starts: resolution of riddles to move forward in the rooms of the castle; harvest of weapons and objects which will help her in the task; fight against monsters and boss until reach her goal.

The whole is made in a funny style, both in drawing and in dialogues. Monsters are completely stupid, and there is a lot of jokes about RPG: the hero who eats literally hearts to regenerate HP, the HP bar made of hearts drawn on papers and maintained between them with adhesive tape, jokes about useless items or achievements... We also collect cards of the bestiary of the game, which describe every character and their tastes in a parodic way. So we learn that some monsters like french fries, that other one is dizzy while it is a flying monster, etc...

The graphic style is original, with a real identity, childish and very colored style. Sounds and music are also very nice. On the other hand, it is a short game, between 3 and 4 hours to fully finish it, that is to say by ending the game, the secondary donjons and by collecting all the objects. Everything depends on your speed to understand and to solve the riddles. However, speedrunners and achievement hunters will be satisfied. Indeed, to get all the achievements, you will need to finish the game several times, and one in particular in less than 15 minutes!

16625787.review:
Ittle Dew is a fun little game that follows its titular protagonist. I'm not very good (read: patient) with most puzzle games but this game manages to pace puzzling, fighting and exploring pretty well. It has a couple of really great challenges in all three departments and all in all is a breath of fresh air.
Unlike some indie games, Ittle Dew has no anoying screenfilling pixel graphics that make you want to break out the NES for some actual retro games. But nice, almost hand-drawn, colourful graphics that are pleasing to the eye. The gameplay is consistent and solid, dialogue whimsical but never boring. 

It's difficult to say anything bad about the game because the whole package is just such a good example of an indie game done right. If anything it isn't a "full title" only in the sense that it isn't a very long game and will last for about 3-4 hours on your first playthrough.

16541781.review: Ittle Dew is a short but humorous Zelda clone that might be worth it on sale for a few bucks. It's a fun distraction and only recommended at a deep discount.

16487109.review:
It's a good game, but from what I saw I thought I was getting a zelda clone or arpg and it's nothing like that, this is entirely a puzzle game. As a puzzle game it's surprisingly challenging and the different mechanics work well together and lend to some interesting stages. The design of the puzzles actually reminds me a lot of Portal in how they're constructed and the lateral thinking that you have to apply sometimes (and not just because there's a portal wand in the game).

 However the game is pretty short, I was able to get the achievement for beating it in 3 hours on my first playthrough and I thought I was taking it slow. There's replay value in that puzzles that are easy with say the portal wand are much much harder when you try to brute force it using just the ice wand, and doing the Wanderer achievement was very difficult and at times I had to use a walkthrough which is something I never do. The collectables are entirely pointless (they even say so in the game), the bosses and combat in general is frustrating and not fun at all, and the entire game can feel shallow but there's fun to be had. I got it for nearly nothing on the humble bundle and I wouldn't recommend paying much more than $5 for it based on its length but if you like puzzle games you'll probably have a lot of fun with it. I just wish they focused more on the puzzles and took out the combat parts of it entirely, since they serve no purpose and will end up pissing you off more than anything.

EDIT: I forgot one of the most important aspects for me which is linux support (if you're running on Windows you can just skip over this). This game does support linux and plays great on it compared to other ports on steam, with fully working achievements unlike say Postal 2 (which still bothers me to this day). HOWEVER the controller support is wonky. The first time I ever started the game I calibrated my controller, and everything worked perfectly. I close the game, restart it, and the controls for the analog stick are completely broken, the character will walk when I dont press anything, will go in the opposite direction of what I tell it to, and generally it's unplayable with the stick now even though it worked perfectly the first time, and recalibration did nothing to fix it. Thankfully I was able to map movement to the dpad instead which was fine, but since I'm using a ps3 controller and the dualshock 3's dpad is garbage it was pretty annoying to control like that, though everything else worked perfectly.

15227329.review:
This game is truely great. I would certainly recommend it to people who like puzzle games.

[h1]Pros[/h1]
[list]
[*]Nice graphics.
[*]A nice mix of some really easy puzzles and some really hard puzzles.
[*]It's quite short, but getting 100% will take quite a bit of time. I feel the length is ok. Any longer and it would have overstayed it's welcome.
[*]You can't really die. When your hearts are empty you simply restart the room.
[*]There is a quick room restart/reset option, or you can simply walk out of a room to reset it.
[*]Completed/solved rooms will mostly stay solved so you can easily travel through them. This even holds for partially solved rooms.
[/list]

[h1]Cons[/h1]
[list]
[*]You can't always complete a puzzle. Sometimes you need other/more tools. I wasted a lot of time and experienced a bunch of frustration before an Internet search told me I couldn't do some of them. But, because you don't know which you can't do, it takes the fun away trying to figure them out.
[*]I wish there was a (better) hint system so you could pass puzzles you really can't solve without help.
[*]The constant backtracking to find puzzles to solve is a useless time waster. There is a teleporting system, but you'll still walk back and forth the same paths countless times.
[*]I personally didn't like the boss fights. I'm not all that dexterous with a controller so failed often. I'm not a big fan of trial-and-error action scenes.
[*]You can't really die, so the enemies are mostly a nuisance that gets in your way. I wouldn't have minded it if the game had only the puzzles.
[/list]

14442901.review:
A part of me really doesn't want to recommend it, but that's just the rage talking.

A short, sweet, puzzle adventure game with great art direction and humor. The main storyline puzzles are fairly simple to figure out, while the side-mission 'trading card' puzzles will probably require you actually sit there and think a bit. Then there's the Master Cave that will likely require most people to devote a rather hefty amount of time to get through those 12 puzzles, as they tend to push the limitations of your items as far as possible. 

But where the puzzles shine, the combat falls completely flat. Your attacks lack any sort of knock back so unless you are backpedaling they will simply walk over you, which is exacerbated by the fact that your sword lacks any reach or arc to its swing, meaning that you will likely be trading hearts with your foes until you perfect the distance. But this isn't a huge flaw as enemies aren't a huge threat and even boss fights are usually more based around item gimmicks than fighting. Usually...

The one, ONE, huge glaring flaw in the game is that the Master Cave I mentioned before, the optional end game with the 12 most difficult, mindbreaking, walkthrough inducing, puzzles in the game... ends in a boss that is nothing more than a button mashing lesson in rage and futility. Your items do nothing. The skills and techniques you've worked on through 4+ hours of gameplay are useless. You are stuck using only the shoddy sword combat mechanics, and praying to every deity under the sun that it will bug out and stop attacking so you can kill it sometime this millenia. A massive black spot on an otherwise great puzzle game. I solved every puzzle, collected every card, but due to stupidly dodgy combat mechanics, a lack of luck, and a lack of perfect precision manual dexterity on my part, I couldn't beat it after a full hour of trying. I've no desire to ever try again, and likely will never play this game again because of that stupid boss. Why devs why... why would you do that...

Combat boss in a puzzle game = not a happy Vekai

14291063.review:
Man, this one was certainly a pleasant surpise. I expected something at least decent but what I got was a great and clever puzzle game with high replayability and amusing dialogue/parody. 

The core puzzle gameplay is based around sliding block puzzles, yes, but with interesting mechanics I've not seen done before, especially not all together in the way this game does. Every puzzle feels unique and fresh, and they range from the simple to the mind-numbingly difficult (though I admit that I looked up solutions to a few in the master cave... the harder ones there are also kind of the weakest, lots of secret mechanic stuff you need to know :s )

On top of that, there are four different ways to complete the game. You can get all three items or any combination of the two, and the paths you can take through the castle are quite different for each 2-combination. I quite enjoyed working out the different ways to make it through to the end, it kept replays fresh and interesting. The achievement set is also pretty great; a few bonus dungeons, 100% collection, and an added challenge to one of the routes for beating the game without harming a few specific enemy types (only possible via one of the four routes, sadly, and there's a bit of a dick move possible right after the final boss if you don't set up the castle properly... but ehh!)

The writing is also amusing, toying with lots of RPG tropes (especially Zelda tropes, which is this game's closest comparison to begin with) but not going overboard. It's very self-aware but clearly the devs loved the kinds of games they're mocking.

The one weakness of the game is the combat, which is very bare-bones and kind of picky; weapon seems to be a bit shorter than it appears on your character, most notably. It's not a big enough flaw to really detract from the overall experience, though.

The main game will probably only run you 3-4 hours by itself, including all the extras, but replaying is worth it even if you're not achievement hunting since it does change the game quite a good bit. I think the price is fair, although I did admittedly get this game via Humble. But in the end I'm quite pleased with this silly little game, it's quite a good time.

13996080.review:
so like there's like a game series called "The Legend of Zelda" that you might have heard of and this game is basically a parody of that, and it's also actually really good

After crashing their makeshift raft into an island (like a certain other game), hotblooded adventuress Ittle Dew and her potion-chugging sidekick Tippsie set out to rob the island's castle of an artifact, which they need to give to the local shopkeeper so that he'll carve them another raft to leave the island with. It's an entirely lighthearted affair filled with charming characters, whimsical creatures, and colorful sights to behold, and the writing, while a bit too self-aware at times, does a good job at poking fun at the conventions of a typical top-down adventure.

Gameplay, as should be clear by now, is like a condensed 2D Zelda. There's a small overworld to explore with caves to spelunk, three main dungeons, two bonus dungeons, and the island's castle, a sprawling, two-story locale which Ittle can only conquer in multiple trips, somewhat like the Tower of Spirits in Spirit Tracks. A variety of enemies roam the island, though it's usually not necessary to kill them because they can only drop hearts, and there are boss battles at the end of each dungeon, including one of the best bonus bosses ever conceived. Treasure comes in the form of Paper Scraps (Heart Pieces), Collectible Cards, and Lunch Money, which Ittle can use at the shop to buy the game's three weapons.

What is particularly interesting about the game is how it offers a lot of choices. The main dungeons can be completed in any order, and they as well as the castle have multiple paths to take through them, the shorter ones — "Professional Shortcuts" — being tougher to traverse. Astoundingly, the adventure can be finished with either all weapons or any combination of two of them, meaning there are four different ways to beat the game; the game even records players' best times for each combination! 

Of course, a Zelda parody wouldn't be complete without puzzles. There are TONS of puzzles in this game, involving familiar concepts like block pushing, switches, mirrors and the like. The mandatory ones generally don't require too much thought, but the aforementioned Professional Shortcuts as well as the overworld caves contain puzzles that tended to take me a good five minutes to solve. One of the bonus dungeons, the Master Cave, is made of twelve incredibly difficult puzzles that really stretched the limits on how Ittle's weapons could interact with each other and the environment; some of them were so devious that I resorted to a guide and I was truly flabbergasted by their solutions. Suffice to say, the puzzles were the highlight of the game for me.

The only iffy part about the gameplay is the combat, specifically Ittle's basic attack. In most 2D Zelda titles, Link swings his sword in a wide arc, but Ittle only swings in a short line directly in front of her. There were several occasions where I would attack only to miss due to the small hitbox, which usually resulted in me taking damage. Thankfully, enemies aren't that tough to take down regardless, and dying only sends Ittle back to the start of the room.

If you haven't watched the trailer for the game on its store page yet, you should do so now because the graphical style of the game is delightful. In addition to being bright and vibrant, the game uses squiggly outlines for characters and moving objects; it reminds me a lot of Ed, Edd n Eddy, which is basically my favorite cartoon to this day. The music, while not as notable, is still pretty good and relaxing.

Overall, Ittle Dew provides a surprising amount of pure fun for its scale and price. I clocked in around six hours my first playthrough and I'm already considering going through the game again with one of the two-weapon routes. Highly recommended.

13947774.review:
Ittle Dew is a little game that stands somewhere between Zelda and Sokoban, with a very humorous tone, and featuring friendly game design, with aspects that can be appreciated by pretty much everyone.

From casual playthroughs, so rock-hard puzzles and 15 minutes speedruns... it's got it all! It's weird, but it's very nice to see how almost every aspect of this game seems to just fit it and provide a great experience, despite its apparent simplicity!

[b][u]Presentation[/u][/b]
Undoubtedly, one of its strongest aspects, especially at first. The cartoon-y [b]artstyle[/b] is very well done, with a pleasant color scheme, very clean, with added lighting effects modernising its look, somewhat. The highlight here for me, though, is the character design. Everyone looks unique, is a clumsy and silly way, and with their own backstory to support them. It's pretty good! 
Another detail I liked is how every line moves slightly, making everything seem more alive.

The [b]music[/b] and [b]sound-effects[/b] didn't standout out too much for me, but fit nicely with the rest of the presentation, and it wasn't bad by any means! Just didn't seem to carry the experience, for me.

I also found the [b]writting[/b] to be funny at times, and it just gave the game a very light-hearted and self-aware tone the whole way through. Ranging from the dialogues with your health-potion drunk companion, to the enemies' entrances and the mocking signposts spread around, everything had something to make fun of.


[b][u]How's the game structured?[/u][/b]
Very much like a Zelda game, actually. You have an island to explore, and go through several dungeons to beat it. There is also some exploration done outside the main and tutorial dungeons.

Near the beginning of the game, you'll find a shop. The shopkeeper tells you he can give you a raft to escape the island, if you get him the artifact in the castle. And off you go. He also has 3 items to sell. You'll find the gold for it in the castle. The game's puzzles revolve around these 3 items: you'll have to combine their abilities in very varied ways to solve the puzzles.

The castle has many shortcuts, that you can take by solving much harder puzzles. If you're stuck, you may as well try another way, or go buy another item. There are many different ways of making progress, too!
The castle puzzles are pretty straighforward, though, so anyone can safely play it without fearing getting frustrated.

Outside the castle, though, there are other smaller dungeon, with harder puzzles. These usually contain Cards with the game's characters. These are merely collectibles, but they're pretty charming too. The puzzles there can also hint at some mechanics you may have not learned throw the tutorial puzzles. 

As a segue, when you have enough gold, you can take one of several portals spread around the castle to fast travel. When you buy an item, you'll be catapulted into another part of the island. These are the tutorial areas. Your items are all stored near the shop, and you'll have to beat the dungeon only with your newfound item. With this, you'll learn how the item works well enough, and do that through play! I think it's a nice way of doing it.

These dungeons also contain several paths and shortcuts. One important thing is that you'll never be able to leave the cave while missing important items. When you leave the dungeon, it will be sealed, but you can rest assured that you haven't missed anything important. This is also told to you after your first dungeon, in a sign post. 
[i]The placing of that was very elegant[/i]: since there are multiple paths, it's very likely that you'll miss part of the map, and become worried after leaving the dungeon. Right when you're worrying about it, the signpost clarifies it for you.
There are many places like this in the game, making tutorialisation nicely paced. [i]Information is often delivered at the right moment![/i]

I think that about covers it.

[b][u]General Mechanics[/u][/b]
This game has both combat and puzzles, although the focus is mainly on the puzzles. There are also some Boss Fights, most of which are more puzzle-driven than combat, although both blend rather nicely, items being multi-purposed.

The combat is very straightforward. Your basic attack attacks the tile in front of you. There are also projectiles attacks. There are several different enemies, some that attack only in front of them, some have projectiles, etc. Different enemies require different approaches. Also, they'll respawn each time you enter the room, but it's never a problem as they're easy to avoid. Some puzzles also reset, but only when the initial conditions are necessary for you to solve another puzzle in the room (or perhaps to use a shortcut).

The only problem I've had with the combat, is how the movement is a bit [b]floaty[/b], and there's a [b]lack of knock-back[/b] with some enemies. The enemies often drop hearts to replenish your health, and the game is overall not punishing in the least, so it's not too big of an issue. 

[b][i]Lack of Punishment[/i][/b]
That's mostly a good thing, but it sometimes holds the player's hand too much. For example, Boss fights have 3-5 phases, and there's usually a checkpoint between each. I've found that mostly unnecessary, taking the little challenge that they provided. I think boss fights should still be a threat!
On the other hand, each time you die, you'll simply reset the room, but never lose progress, or collectibles at all. That's a very welcome thing! It's always annoying to do 4-5 rooms again when you die, or lose progress over a simple miss-step.


The [b]puzzles[/b] are basically Sokoban, with a few twists. You have 3 items: a Flaming Sword, a Freezing Wand, and a Teleporting Wand.
The sword can set bombs on fire, to explode after a few seconds. The Freezing Wand can freeze enemies and blocks (making them very slippery when you push them, and also breakable), and can also freeze a wall, making it reflective.
The Teleporting Wand can create a Green block anywhere. If you hit bombs or enemies with the projectile, they'll teleport over to that block. This is basically all you need to know.
You combine these techniques with some more subtle quirks to the tiles and timing, and you can be faced with some evil difficult puzzles.


Difficulty.
[b][i]Ittle Dew sets its casual from its hardcore puzzles[/i][/b]
Usually, to beat the game, you have some fairly easy puzzles. To collect the cards, it's a different matter (although mostly doable). There's a final dungeon with 12 puzzles however, that is really hard! At least for someone inexperienced in Sokoban. I often had to peek into a walkthrough, and was constantly surprised with a new way of combining my items.

[i]Precision and Perfection rather than simply solving a puzzle[/i]
The problem is that some of these puzzles required extremely precise timing, with the game's controls don't provide very well, in my opinion. Also, these puzzles constantly made you restart at every wrong move. A time rewinding mechanic would be welcome, even if just on this cave. I had to restart these puzzles many times, making it a bit too frustrating. It wasn't just a puzzle to solve, it was something that heavily relied on execution, which I'm not a fan of.

Then again, these were completely optional! And the game warned you that they were hard. If you complete it, you'll get some more cards, and also Development info, which is very cool!

H.Mention: The castle can be solved with ANY combination of 2 items. I'm very impressed with this! The castle is so nicely designed that you can beat it with any combination of the two items, and the game aknowledges that with achievements. Also for cards, speed, etc.
There are many ways of playing Ittle Dew, which is why I think it's a neatly designed game. Many ways that tie together brilliantly!
Full Recommendation. Also, check Card City Nights!

13891799.review: I tried to like the game, but its just horrible.

13888545.review:
Ittle Dew is a 2D puzzle adventure game. Basically, it's like a 2D Legend of Zelda game with a heavy focus on the puzzles. You're washed up on a mysterious island and, as any good adventurer does, you start to adventure. It's pretty straightforward in terms of adventuring. You go from dungeon to dungeon as they become available to you, work on puzzles with the dungeons in order to complete them, and then receive items to help you progress further. Upon getting an item, you generally are sent to a new area without the other items, forcing you to get acquainted with the new item and its uses before being able to combine the uses of all your items. There are a few optional shortcuts and slightly hidden puzzles you can go after, which is nice for even more puzzle solving. It is also entire possible to complete the game without getting all of the items. You can beat it with a few combinations of a few items. These are reflected in the achivements, but... I'll be honest, I had enough trouble with the main game using everything. There's also some funny little dialogues going on in parts of the game which give it some life and keep things from getting too harsh on your brain. Almost like little rewards for continuing. And there are boss fights which will give some action to your problem solving skills. A nice blend for the game.

There are a few downsides though, as all games have. One is that the game is rather short. Most of the playtime here will be from getting stuck on tricky puzzles. There's not much adventuring, as most of the places you go to are rather straightforward and without missable secrets. Even the optional puzzles are pretty easy to find. So I guess there could've been more adventure for my taste. Also, the combat is a little rough. It just feels a bit stiff and non responsive. There's less focus on it, but still, a little more fluidity might have been nice. Not a big deal, though. You can adjust. There were some pretty interesting puzzles, some involving good timing, but the game doesn't do a great job of teaching you the timing based techniques used later in the game. Also, there's an awful lot of block puzzles, so... if you don't like those... stay away.

Overall, it's a pretty cool game. Is it worth the ten dollar price tag? Well, if you're a Zelda fan or a puzzle fan, yes. It's definitely worth checking out. For others? Possibly wait for a sale, or just give it a shot. It's a decent price for what you get. It has some neat sound and a fun art style. The music went well the the mood. It's definitely something anyone could enjoy, but recommended for only the Zelda fans or puzzle crowd, I'd say. If you're looking for more adventure, it may not be your cup of tea. And I must say that, even though it is a bit on the short side, it doesn't FEEL short. It feels like a full game, and that's where it counts. I'd give Ittle Dew 7/10. Good, solid game, but geared more towards the puzzle minded for sure.

A game made for fans of A Link to the Past and other similar 2D Zelda games.  It is, however, more of a parody than a true zelda-esque title, and the game isn't terribly afraid of showing it.  It's humorous, cute, and brings its own spice to the genre.  Its puzzles can be incredibly challenging and rather unforgiving at times, but the reward is... usually pretty good.  Definitely worth it if you like puzzle/adventure games in the vein of old NES/SNES-era titles.  Actually, it's still worth a buy even if you're not into those things.  It's a pretty good game.  I don't understand why it got such a low Metacritic score.
One problem I had with it: If you screw up a puzzle, you have to leave the room.  This can get very frustrating, very fast.  Other than that, though, I'm a fan.

Este pequeño Indie ha sido toda una sorpresa, lo conseguí en un Humble Bundle, y para ser sincero después de jugar a los otros que venían en el pack esperaba que este fuese bastante simplón.

Sin embargo me ha sorprendido con una buena cantidad de puzles, todos muy bien pensados y muy pulidos que te harán estrujarte los sesos bastante rato. Tiene esa estética dibujada con tableta gráfica tan común en los juegos independientes, pero todos los elementos se integran a la perfección y es bastante agradable a la vista.

El PVE a veces es un poco injusto, hasta el enemigo más lento puede tocarte en ángulos en los que tu no puedes hacer nada, por no hablar de los enemigos que atacan a distancia, que te darán el 90% de las veces

Los logros te fuerzan a pasarte el juego varias veces, algo que no me suele gustar en esta clase de juegos, sin embargo te dará unas cuantas horas de diversión con puzles muy buenos

Soy un gran amante de la saga de Zelda y este juego me ha recordado mucho a los de Nintendo DS, obviamente a escala reducida, pero si lo encuentras de oferta lo recomiendo

Ittle Dew est un jeu certe court mais aussi très prenant. 


C'est un jeu d'aventure en 2d isométrique appelé communément zelda-like où vous incarné une jeune aventurière échouant sur une île sur laquelle elle vivra de "grandes" aventures. 

Rappelant le très célèbre "Goof Troop", ce jeu rempli d'humour et ponctué de références discrètes ( comme par exemple le petit clin d'œil à "Secret of Mana" et son fameux "voyage canon")  ravira les afionados d'énigmes car même si le jeu reste très simple d'accès dans son ensemble, venir à bout des énigmes de la caverne légendaire demandera du temps et de la réflexion. 

En bref, Ittle Dew mérite emplement qu'on s'interresse à lui et ne fera pas regretté les quelques heures passé à explorer l'île et son château. De plus, on le retrouve souvent à des prix plus qu'abordables, que demande le peuple ?!?

13625495.review:
Best Zelda port for PC hands down!

Note the following changes: 

[list]
[*]The protagonist is no longer a mute imp, but an opinionated adventurer. Oh, and a girl. 
[*]Your annoying fairy guide is now a snarky little fox with wings that is constantly drinking -something-.
[*]Instead of heart pieces, you collect scraps of paper that, when taped together, you can draw a heart in. 
[*]Oh, hearts are deliciously edible, and not magically absorbed.
[/list]

I HIGHLY recommend this to all Zelda fans. The gameplay is nearly identical, and there are little nods to Zelda within the game (which makes me believe that the devs are big fans, too). I bought this on a whim and am VERY EXCITED to play this game. WORTH EVERY PENNY AND MORE. 10/10!!

13619072.review:
There's this time in everyone life where after a very long time you find something precious. That precious thing captivates your soul and mind.  

For me, it was this game. First time in my gaming history I managed to complete a game in 1 playthrough without getting bored for a single second.  It was like a time warp.  

Anyways, lets quit the drama and let me present you with a Short, sweet review just like the game.  

Pros:
+ Amazing gameplay. It's downright fun.
+ Cleverly designed puzzles.
...+ The puzzles are not super hard niether are they super easy.
...+ It's a perfect mixture of hard yet non-frustating puzzle. Exactly what I look for in a VIDEO GAME.
+ Short and nice story. It's not bland like other puzzle games.
+ It's not serious either, the mood is quite humours and vibrant.
+ The game does not overstay it's welcome.
...+ Fun fact: You can finish the game in under 15 minutes.
+ It offers pretty good replaybility.
...+ It's highly likely that you won't solve all the puzzles in your first playthrough.
...+ There are 3 different ways to play this game. (Each of which grants a different achievement too)

Cons:
- There was only exactly ONE situation where I thought the game/floor/level design could have been better. 
- And that's an extremely low number for a puzzle game. (or any game tbh)

I got this game as a gift from a friend who bought it from humble bundle for $1.00 along with a couple of other games. But I'd say this game is worth it's full price if you're a completionist. If not, it's still worth picking up on -50% or less.

13606126.review:
일단은 젤다 시리즈의 테이스트가 강하게 느껴지는 퍼즐 해결형 RPG인데.. 스크린샷 몇장만 보고 판단하지 말자. 이거 꽤 잘 만든 게임이다.

우선 게임의 근간을 이루는 퍼즐의 디자인이 정말 절묘한 수준이다. 젤다 시리즈보다는 소규모의 오밀조밀한 퍼즐들로 가득 차 있는데, 와 이걸 이렇게 깨라고 만들어뒀네! 싶으면서도 동시에 머리를 굴려보면 누구나 해답을 얻을 있는 수 있을 정도로 딱 알맞은 난이도를 내세우고 있다. 너무 쉬울 것 같다고? 걱정마시라. 퍼즐에 강한 플레이어는 인위적으로 사용하는 아이템을 제한하거나 타임어택용 지름길을 개척하여 좀 더 어려운 난이도로 진행할 수 있으며(물론 이렇게 클리어 하면 도전과제 달성은 덤), 본편의 던전 외에 12개의 하드코어한 퍼즐로 구성된 전문가용 던전 또한 보너스로 존재한다. 본 작성자의 경우 퍼즐이 게임의 흐름을 끊어먹는 게임을 매우 싫어하는 편인데도 이 게임은 정말 재미있게 즐길 수 있었다.

시나리오의 경우 딱히 스토리라고 부를 만한 이야기의 큰 흐름은 없지만 게임 내내 시니컬 하면서도 실소를 자아내게 하는, 장르적 클리셰를 비꼰 개그들로 가득 차 있다. HP를 회복하는 하트아이템을 보고 '너 지금 심장을 먹는거야? ㅇㅇ 근데 이거 맛있다?!' 뭐 이런식으로 표현한다거나, 갤러리 특전을 들어있는 상자를 열때 '아무것도 없는데? ㄴㄴ 나가서 옵션 들어가면 추가되어 있음' 이런 식으로 이야기 한다던가.. 전반적으로 가볍고 유쾌하면서도 메이저 게임에서는 보기 어려운 인디 특유의 약기운이 느껴지는 그런 분위기이다. 

이런 재미들로 가득 차 있음에도 불구하고 게임의 볼륨이 너무 작다는 것은 아쉬운 점중 하나이다. 공략을 참조하지 않고 모든 콜렉팅 아이템을 모으면서 본편을 클리어 하는데에 대략 6시간 정도면 충분할 정도이다. 물론 앞서 언급한대로 전문가용 던전, 아이템 사용을 제한하는 학대플레이, 그리고 타임어택과 같은 추가적인 즐길거리들이 있지만 그래도 아쉬운 건 아쉬운 거다. 본편을 진행하는 내내 너무나도 즐거웠기에 볼륨에 대한 아쉬움이 더욱 크게 다가온다. 개발자도 이러한 점을 인지를 하고 있는지, 추가로 제공되는 던전을 DLC가 아닌 업데이트의 형태로 무료제공한 바가 있다. 오오 개발자님 오오..

결론적으로 꽤 할만한, 그리고 플레이 하는 내내 빠져들만한 게임이다. 단순히 메타크리틱의 점수만 보고 졸작이라 평가하거나, 스크린샷만을 보고 젤다 짝퉁으로 치부한며 넘겨버리기에는 게임이 주는 재미가 너무 컷기에 한 명이라도 더 이 게임을 접할 수 있기를 바라는 마음으로 평가를 작성해 본다. 솔까 번들로도 몇번 풀렸던 게임이라 당신 라이브러리에도 분명 있을거다. 있는지도 모른채 짱박아 두지 말고 일단 설치하고 플레이를 해보길 권하는 바이다.

13263188.review:
Ittle Dew is a compact, Zelda-like experience that's appropriate for kids and adults. It also comes packed with a sense of humor and plenty of optional puzzles should the main story not satisfy your thirst for solving. The game also encourages multiple runs and has achievements encouraging different styles of play.

You can expect to wield four different tools that interact with each other different and have special properties waiting to be used. One of my favorite moments in Ittle Dew was the time I discovered how to launch enemies into the heavens by accident. These tools also add variety to the combat with their different applications.

The combat seems okay for the most part. A certain few enemy types are not easily dispatched which can be annoying if you're stuck in a room with four of them. For some reason, there's some awkwardness when using the stick/sword for fighting. I tend to bump into enemies a lot before striking, but the game is forgiving with death (and failed puzzles) and only resets the room.

The art design is clean and cutesy. I do enjoy how the trees are very animated. The colors are well chosen. I have no complaints here.

Ittle Dew will provide quite a bit of entertainment depending on your skill level with its puzzles. You'll probably have a good time and if you're stuck, call on Tippsie or refer to a guide if even Tippsie can't help you. I highly recommend collecting the in-game card collectibles as you play. They're quite funny.

13115337.review:
The generally accepted reason for why there aren’t more games like The Legend Of Zelda is that they’re just too hard to make. Ocarina Of Time is still widely accepted as the best game ever made, but that in itself implies that its creation was not a trivial task. There have been attempts to copy the formula, from early titles like Golden Axe Warrior through to Alundra, 3D Dot Game Heroes, and Ōkami, but not only are these efforts rare but they’ve generally been commercial failures.

That is likely to be the real reason for the lack of similar games, but such market realities are not something that indie developers generally worry about. Which is good because, despite a few caveats, Ittle Dew is one of the most enjoyable Zelda-a-likes we’ve played in years.

Despite what it may look like Ittle Dew is not a straight clone, but it does have perhaps the most legitimate excuse for copying another game: comedy. Ittle Dew isn’t just a love letter to the Zelda games it’s also a parody of them, and its spunky heroine Ittle and her Navi stand-in Tippsie (a wonderfully cynical magic fox) gently poke fun at the series’ specific peculiarities and those of gaming in general.

Tippsie in particular is hilarious, as she reacts with varying degrees of disgust to ordinary Zelda tropes, such as Ittle eating a heart to get more health to her quaffing potions when she’s not looking. Joking about smashing pots and what enemies do all day as they stand around in lonely dungeons may seem like obvious targets, but as we’ve often lamented games are strangely reticent to ever poke fun at their sillier traditions.

The jovial mood is enhanced further by the wonderful visuals, but despite the art style being very different from any official Zelda game overall Ittle Dew still ends up looking lawyer-worryingly similar. The game is scheduled for release on Wii U later in the year though so we assume that Nintendo gets the joke as well.

Ittle has a much more mercenary approach to her explorations than Link, happily stuffing her pockets with treasure as she goes about adventuring. Even the artefact she’s trying to obtain from a nearby castle is only to bribe a shopkeeper to build her a ship to get home. Although he does at least offer to sell her three items vital to her mission: a fire sword, an ice wand, and a portal-creating magic wand.

Unusually for a Zelda game these are the only three items in the whole game, which is certainly a bold choice. But despite all the puzzles being solved using only one or more of the items it’s disappointing that the meat of most of them still revolves around pushing blocks and hitting switches. In the traditional manner there are torches and bombs to be lit, pressure pads to stand on, and doors to unlock. 

The puzzles might not be very imaginative but they are well designed and often have multiple solutions. You can even beat the entire game using any random combination of just two of the items. Some of the puzzles are very hard but the game isn’t interested in punishing you, only challenging you, and there’s a wide range of helpful hints given out by Tippsie.

The dungeon-like areas are very much the focus of the game and although there are overworld areas they’re smaller and less interactive than real Zelda games. The combat is also significantly less interesting, being barely any more nuanced than the original NES game and offering zero reward beyond extra health. The bosses are a mostly decent bunch though and also get some of the best lines.

Ittle Dew is rather short, at around three to four hours, although you’ll need much longer to collect everything and beat the optional Master Cave (the only truly difficult challenge in the whole thing). But for only a tenner you get a download that is not only fun but funny – a game that is amusingly self-aware but uses this as a means to enhance the experience and not just make excuses for it.

[h1][b]Recommended[/b][/h1]

12824466.review:
A fun little puzzle game with nice artwork.  Don't let the screenshots or heavily inspired Link to the Past aesthetic fool you though, Ittle Dew is about 98% block puzzles and 2% other stuff.  Do not go into this expecting an action-rpg or some kind of dungeon romp with the occasional puzzle.  It's all puzzles and your enjoyment of them will make or break the game for you.

There are three items used in puzzles: fire sword, ice wand and portal blocks/teleportation.  This isn't anywhere as limiting as it may seem and the game's puzzle design is very tight and well-done.  Ittle Dew gets a lot of mileage with the different ways it incorporates using the tools together to solve puzzles.  I didn't realize until after I finished it that you can beat the game by only collecting two of the three items and with any combination of the two.   It adds a ton of replay value for future playthroughs.  The game also has "shortcut paths", basically hard puzzles that you can use to skip chunks of the game and beat it in less than twenty minutes if you know what to do.  Stuff like beating the game with different combos of items and the shortcut puzzles are cool mechanics/design decisions and I like to seeing them even if I don't necessary plan on ever using them myself.

The cartoony art is very nice and vivid.  The UI is simple and efficient.  You don't have to walk out of a room to reset a failed puzzle, you can just hit start and hit reset room to save yourself the needless back and forth you'd find in similar games.  The game lets you know how many items are in each area and most collectible item rooms will let you know if you have the correct item to solve the puzzle so you don't spend time beating your head against the wall trying to solve a puzzle you don't have the right item for.  There's just a lot of little things the game does to make playing it a non-aggravating experience.

In short, if you're down with games that heavily involve pushing blocks and solving puzzles, you'll probably have a solid time with Ittle Dew.  Just don't head into it expecting a Zelda-ish game.

12492357.review:
This is an unreasonably good game.  I do list a few nitpicks below, but they don't wreck the game.

[b]Pros[/b]
First, the positive: This game is cleverly designed, adorable, and a lot of fun.  I enjoyed playing it, and I hope to see a sequel someday.  The puzzles were very well-presented, giving you opportunities to learn the tools before being thrown into a terrifying challenge.  You're always ready, but the puzzles always stretch you and I, for one, walked away feeling satisfied with my accomplishments.

There are only 3 tools, and yet... the ways they're used are magnificent.  You don't have a bag of gimmicky gadgets to fumble through; instead each puzzle uses one, two or three tools in really clever ways, and I often felt brilliant when I completed them.

The main game can be defeated when you have all three tools... but you don't need all three.  You can also beat the game with any combination of only two tools, which just warps my mind.  The puzzles felt so tight and so tough, and I was amazed to discover I could complete them with even less.  There's also various side dungeons where you can pick up more health, or collect optional cards.  The real reward is the feeling of victory and the wild ego boost that comes with completing them all by yourself, simply for fun.

For a really steep challenge, there's also an optional master dungeon that requires all three tools and some really clever thinking.  I strongly recommend it.

The characters and story are adorable and funny.  I liked them.  The animations are excellent, and I loved the look and feel of Ittle's world.  I also liked Ittle herself... she's charming, if devious.  Her little flying helper is also fun.  They do a good job of making fun of their genre, while adding a lot of their own character as well (which is more important than the parody, and done well).

[b]Cons:[/b]
A few minor niggles include:
-A bit of unclarity in hitboxes and figuring out whether an attack will hit.  It's not a huge deal, since combat is secondary to the puzzles and even this issue doesn't make the combat unfun at all.
-On a couple occasions, the master dungeon pulled some unwarranted tricks, like requiring incredibly fast movement (down to the millisecond) to be in position in time to act or stop a block, which felt like a deviation from the formula that makes the game good (clever puzzle solving, not brutal platforming skill)

But the major issue?

I was intensely offended by the optional side-boss fight.  Instead of having you employ all the great tricks you've learned just to reach him, he throws ALL of that away... he is instead just a standard run & stab boss battle, and a brutally unfair one at that (I eventually gave up).  Only your sword matters; you will not use the other tools at all (trying will get you killed repeatedly).  The best strategies I've read for beating him were simply to have lots of health and be fast.  It requires incredibly tight controls, which this game doesn't have, so a lot of it is luck and cheesing bugs and quirks in the AI and movement.  This was not a good climax to the otherwise brilliantly designed master dungeon; instead it was a malicious slap in the face, and god it hurt.

It still leaves me a bit grumpy, even after all these months.  >:(

But does this ruin the game?  NO!  It felt anti-climactic and I did feel betrayed and put upon by the developers, but the rest of the game is so good, that this just fades into background noise in comparison.

[b]Summary[/b]
9/10.  This is a fantastic game.  Yes, I'm still intensely bitter about the optional boss (RAAAAGE!!!!), but that doesn't destroy the pure, unfiltered joy that is the rest of this game.  Everything in the main game and optional dungeons, save for that side boss, is excellent.  I still look back with extreme fondness!  I'm looking forward to playing the free Halloween update soon, which was a really cool thing for them to add.

12429161.review:
The game is full of cleverly designed puzzles and a great hint system, with very few puzzles feeling like they were unnecessary. The game is a little short, but at this pricepoint it does achieve a respectable 3-4 hours on average the first time, but obviously in less time if you don't do the treasure puzzles. It also has a good amount of replay value. Loads of puzzles can be solved in several ways and there are plenty of shortcuts that require some serious thinking to get through. You can buy the 3 main items in whatever order you want (buying the Ice Wand - the most expensive item - first makes the game significantly harder), you can even reach and beat the last boss without all the items and there are even achievements for doing so; there are 4 separate last boss fights depending on which items you have.
Then there's also speed-running functionality built into the game. You can apparently finish the game in 15minutes somehow... I could barely do it under an hour when I tried (without memorizing all the puzzles tho).

And let's not forget the lovely graphics and funny dialogue. The "wobble" graphics are very unique, quite unlike anything I've ever seen. Kind of like a comic-book game in movement? That's probably the best way I can describe it.

The game does have one pretty poor part though: the combat. It's just clunky and kind of serves more as a way to add variation between puzzles. I can't say I've enjoyed the combat in any isometric 4-directional movement game though, so it might not be something everyone is bothered by. The boss fights are better than the other fights as they kind of involve puzzles in the fight.


It's a great puzzle game well worth playing. If you're even remotely interested in puzzle games I would recommend giving this one a try.

This is Zelda in everything but name. There is slightly more emphasis on puzzle solving to combat, but it's all there.

Cute graphics and funny dialogue as well. The levels deserve special mention, they are flawlessly designed, especially when you consider that the layout was specifically crafted to be completable while missing any one of the three key items, which is beyond impressive from a design perspective. It does this without sacrificing difficulty either. Sure, some of the bits are hand-holdy easy, but jesus, I gave up on the master cave ONE PUZZLE IN, and the main castle is also nice and challenging.

It's not a brief game. Sure, you could probably blitz through it in 2 hours or so, but its hard to ignore all of the optional chests taunting you on your minimap. For such a colourful game, it also gets surprisingly dark... I'm sure this was planned, but oh man, those ghosts...

Huge, positive reccomendation from me, especially if you're a Zelda fan.

Un petit jeu d'énigme sympatoche, déguisé en Zelda-like. Oui car ce n'est pas un Zelda-like accompli, le focus étant vraiment mis sur les énigmes, il y a très peu de vrai exploration et le maniement du personnage pour les combats est vraiment très raide, pas agréable du tout. Cependant l'univers débile à souhait mérite qu'on s'y intéresse! 

Le gros plus à mon sens, c'est que la progression tout au long du jeu au sein du Donjon-central est très libre, et en fonction des objets que l'on achètera/possédera/utilisera, celui-ci sera plus ou moins facile. Il y a moyen d'être créatif, et de finir le jeu en se privant d'un objet sur les trois que compte le jeu! Ou, si on trouve ça trop difficile, d'utiliser les trois à la fois. 

En ce sens, il se rapproche du dernier Zelda 3DS qui se voulait plus libre dans le choix des Donjons, et le surpasse même dans cette approche, car Ittle Dew est conçu pour qu'on puisse littéralement couper certaines parties du jeu, si on est suffisament malin pour gruger les énigmes avec moins d'objets! Ce que le Zelda 3DS ne permettat pas, le "choix" étant assez illusoire au final.

If you want a game kind of like a 2D Zelda but without the requirement of 30+ hours then this is a great choice. It relies a lot more heavily on block-manipulation puzzles, but it does so with a smart trio of tools that create an interesting variety of gameplay and rewards clever thinking.

11390455.review:
As someone who plays little to no puzzle games; this game did a good enough job twisting the genre to excuse that bias anyway. I did not expect to like this game all that much; I had picked it up in a bundle this was one of the lesser reasons for me to want to pick up the bundle; at the time. After having played it to completion at least once; I can safely say that it feels like a more puzzily version of an old Legend of Zelda game, which is nice. 

Pros

The Art Style - I really enjoyed the art style. It's very comically utitilized throughout the game, and suited the mood perfectly throughout.

The Difficulty - I felt the difficulty was really well realized. I rarely ran into puzzles or situations that gave me any significant trouble; there were a few times I felt challenged but overall the balance was well realized.

The Music - I liked the music. It was ominous where necessary, as well as jaunty where needed. Could get rather old if stuck on a puzzle, but otherwise it was utilized effectively.

Cons

The Gameplay - This is more a subjective gripe than anything else; I felt that the gameplay could be rather clunky at times. I think my major issue was more often related to the hit box of the character; there were times, especially when dealing with projectiles, where I would get hit and not feel like it was well represented. It was not common, but happened enough to be annoying. I think the perspective is what complicated it further at times.

The Puzzles - Once again, subjective gripe. I don't like puzzles. This game has them in spades. They're all right, but some were complicated enough to frustrate me and pull me out of the experience.

The Price Point - I hate bringing it up, but the "cost-per-hour" price point is rather lackluster here. True, you can always replay through the game and try to do so differently than before; but I personally don't have much motivation to do so. That said, if you don't mind the price point, you will be in for a good short experience; unless you're even worse at puzzles than I am, in which case you'll likely get your money's worth.

At the end of the day I do enjoy this game. It's surprising too given my lack of mirth for puzzle games as a whole, but at the right price point it's a nice experience. I wouldn't recommend this game over many others; but if you find it for cheap enough during a sale I wouldn't recommend against it. Cautiously recommended.

Una especie de Zelda, pero mas orientado a la resolución de puzles y al ingenio que a matar bichos. A mi gusto, una obra maestra en cuanto a rompecabezas. La forma en la que esta hecho el juego de que puedas pasártelo utilizando únicamente 2 de los tres objetos que se presentan en cualquiera de sus combinaciones da lugar a poder completar el juego de 4 formas prácticamente distintas, (en la de usar los 3 objetos si quieres completarlo al 100% repetirás lo mismo que en las otras 3).

Cuenta con puzles de la trama principal, y un montón de puzles secundarios, así como una "Cueva Maestra" que pondrá a prueba vuestra inteligencia y ¡ojo! no es para nada sencilla ya os lo digo xD.

Los bosses están como tienen que estar hechos en este tipo de juegos, para matarlos tienes que hacer uso de los objetos conseguidos en cada parte, por lo que cada batalla con cada boss es diferente.

Aunque el juego se puede completar en menos de 15 minutos (como requiere un logro). Conseguir todas las cartas, papeles de vida y todo al 100% en una de las partidas, lleva a unas 3h (y mirando en Internet unos cuantos puzles).

No es un juego muy largo, pero es muy ingenioso, y si no quieres mirar absolutamente nada en Internet y quieres poner 100% a prueba tu ingenio verás que algunos puzles pueden llegar a costarte más de 30m (no se hace pesado), con lo que el juego se alarga bastante.

11221273.review:
Ένα παιχνίδι γρίφων που ξέρει καλά την δουλειά του, μπορεί να σας κρατήσει ώρες μπροστά από την οθόνη κάτι το οποίο θα το ευχαριστηθείτε.

Όταν θα τελειώσετε για πρώτη φορά το παιχνίδι τα Achievements θα είναι εκεί για να σας κρατήσουν περισσότερες ώρες πάνω από το πληκτρολόγιο (ή το χειριστήριο).

Φυσικά δεν θα μπορούσα να αφήσω τα υπέροχα γραφικά έξω από την κριτική, οι υπέροχες ζωγραφιές που ντύνουν το παιχνίδι με άφησαν έκπληκτο.

Προσωπικά δοκίμασα το παιχνίδι με keyboard & mouse αλλά και με gamepad, και θα προτείνω με κλειστά τα μάτια να το παίξετε με gamepad καθώς κάνει την διαχείριση του χαρακτήρα ευκολότερη.

Υπέρ:
* Καταπληκτικοί γρίφοι που σε βάζουν σε σκέψη.
* Όμορφα γραφικά που δεν κουράζουν.
* Πολλά διαφορετικά path και συνδυασμοί για να τελειώσεις το παιχνίδι.
* Achievements που σε κάνουν να αναρωτιέσαι μέχρι που μπορείς να φτάσεις.

Κατά:
* Μερικοί γρίφοι είναι πραγματικά σπαστικοί, με αποτέλεσμα να σου σπάνε τα νεύρα

Score: 9/10

11207126.review:
ゼルダ風のパズルアクションゲーム。
アイテムを手に入れたり、特定の敵を倒したり、ブロックをどうにかしたりすると道が開けていく。
キャラクターは多彩でボスキャラもいるけど、どちらかというとパズル寄り。ボーナスでパズルに特化したステージも２０面くらい用意されている。
後半のパズルはタイミングも重要になってきて一手間違うとハマるけど、隣の部屋に行って戻ってくればやり直しが出来る。ポーズメニューからも選択可。
アクションゲームとしての難易度は低い方だけど、ボスキャラなどはステージ内の仕掛けをうまく使って倒さないといけない。
敵キャラはみんな個性的。火を付けると燃えちゃう謎の爺さんもいる。通せんぼしているクリスタルブロックも何だか個性的。そんなキャラクターを描いたカードを集める要素もある。私はこの無気力な絵柄に惹かれて購入しました。
大作ゲームの合間に息抜きに遊びたいゲーム。Card City Nightsと一緒に買うと吉。

クリアしたのは今年初めくらいでしたが、アップデートで日本語に対応したので再プレイしています。
ストーリー…という程の物でもないけど、キャラクター同士の掛け合いが解ると遊んでいて楽しいです。

11199039.review:
A very endearing, traditional but fresh action adventure.

The gameplay is very Zelda with puzzle-heavy top-down rooms and palace-like dungeons for each tool you acquire. The tools are very different from what you'll find in Zelda games, though, and there's a lot of focus on having them interact with each other - one puzzle may have you freeze a block to let it slide across that spike wall and then freeze and teleport a bomb so its detonation syncs with you lighting a brazier.

Be aware that it doesn't take long to finish the game, but its replay value is high because the path through the castle is nonlinear, there's a lot of optional treasure/puzzles, and extra-hard shortcuts encourage challenge and speedruns. The limited game length also means that a lot of effort could go into each individual room - nothing feels rushed, and the puzzles use available game mechanics to their fullest potential.

Ittle Dew's strongest point of the game is the irreverent yet cute, self-aware humour. Quirky enemy design, expressive hand-drawn graphics and the music support the atmosphere very well.

Combat is rather basic and more about approaching strategically or outsmarting enemies than about the actual process of beating them up, but still a nice diversion between puzzles.

If you care about silly dialogue, clever puzzles and exploring different routes through the same dungeon, this is for you. If you like long, linear games with a focus on combat and are a dialogue-skipper or prefer serious storylines, you're looking in the wrong place though.

11015340.review:
If you like 2D Zelda games, speedrunning and funny dialogue then get Ittle Dew. Its on here and the Wii U eshop for$9.99. Its hella nice. Yeah go get it. Unless you don't like any of those, then keep moving and ignore this review.

Alright, I'll actually talk about the game. So you're an adventurer named Ittle Dew and her sidekick Tippsie are on a raft when they bump into a rock and crash on the shore of an island. After going through a short tutorial cave, there's a big castle you come across filled with weird inhabitants who wear suits and tend to be wacky. Outside the castle is Itan, who runs a shop. You can find treasure chests in the castle with coins and you use those to go towards getting items from the shop. Well, you pay Itan and he launches you to a dungeon that the item is at (a fire sword in a fire cave/volcano, an ice wand in an ice cave/dungeon, and a portal wand in the woods). Each dungeon contains a shortcut that can help you get to the boss faster (most likely than not you're gonna use these if you're speedrunning but they do help you finish the dungeons faster supposing you can figure out the puzzle for each shortcut). Depending on the combination of the items you collect (you need at least 2 to get through the castle to the final boss), you can take different routes through the castle to get to the end.

Aside from the items I previously mentioned, there are also collectible cards you can find in chests throughout the game that have a picture of a character or enemy in the game along with info on them (they go towards an achievement) and you can find scraps of paper in chests as well that go towards increasing your heart count (4 pieces make a new heart a la Legend of Zelda heart containers, this is also for an achievement if you find them all).

This game will test you and your thinking skills. Sometimes puzzles are simple like press all the switches or kill all the enemies or hit switches. Other times, you might take a while to solve a puzzle only to be stumped by the next one. Two optional bonus dungeons (The Master Cave and, as of October 31, 2013, the Compost Crypt) contain even tougher brain scratchers and while not necessary or important to the plot (I did say optional, after all), you do get an achievement, one per dungeon upon completing them and there's cards in the Master Dungeon so you'd have to complete it if you were gunning for all the cards. Think of them as advanced puzzles, more or less.

Lastly, the dialouge is quite humorous. All the characters have a self-aware feel to them when they speak, like they know they're in a video game. There's even call backs/shout outs to older 2D Zelda games like A Link to the Past or Zelda 1. It knows what its doing and you just go with it cause why not. Even the art style is appealing to the eyes.

I've probably harped on long enough but maybe this will convince you to at least check out Ittle Dew. Look, if you like the old school 2D Zelda games or know someone that does, then this game might be for you/them. Hopefully I've said more than enough to peak your interest B^)

10737590.review: Drawn to it by its art style, the game won me by its quirky sense of humour, skillful breaking of the fourth wall and its soundtrack, seriously, the castle, where you'll probably spend the majority of the time, has a catchy tune, which, you know, is a good thing since spending an hour listening to the same thing can get a tad bit tiring. The makers said the game is designed in a way to allow speed running and it shows, with best times going as low as 10 minutes. This allows many modes of play, adding variety to playthroughs. The items you recieve can be gotten in any order, and you don't even need all of them to complete the story, although catching them all surely helps solving some puzzles. The bosses aren't really given much backstory, as any other character really, but this may have been necessary, seeing as having loads of story in a game this short would detract from the gameplay. However, tidbits of information are scattered throughout the game and reading them adds some depth to the world of Ittle Dew. Some of the harder puzzles can be a little tricky to solve since the game doesn't tell you a couple of abilities one of your items has, nothing that a little thinking wouldn't solve, but seeing each new skill having a small tutorial, one could get a slightly confused. Ittle Dew is an adorable little game that really shows the developers put a lot of care in making it as fun and endearing as possible, while maintaing its unique humour.

10596113.review:
■概要
孤島に漂着した"イトル"が島からの脱出を試みる
見下ろし型パズルアクションゲーム。

フィールドではアクション主体のダンジョン探し、
ダンジョン内ではパズル+アクションで構成されている。
まさに ”2D時代のゼルダの伝説” を思い起こさせる。

■ゲームプレイ
主人公のイトルを始めとする可愛らしいキャラクター達、
緑生い茂るフィールド、独特の雰囲気を持った台詞回しなど
見た目には明るく軽快な印象を与えてくれる。

一方アクション面では、
四方のみへの攻撃、またその最中の長い硬直、
やや直感的ではない当たり判定など
ストレスを感じさせる要因があり、こちらはやや残念。

アイテムが手に入る度に出来ることが増え
パズルへのアプローチの仕方が変わるシステムは十分に機能しており
難易度も"通常プレイ"なら十分に考えれば詰まることは無く、
解いた時に快感を与えてくれる程度とバランスは悪くない。
さらにパズル要素に傾倒したダンジョンもメインストーリーとは別に
用意されており、かなり骨のある難易度のパズルにも挑戦できる。

■総合
ボリュームは、
初プレイかつ全てのアイテムを回収した場合でも数時間程度。
「15分以内にクリアしろ」の実績が示す通り、
お世辞にも大きいとは言えない。

特筆すべきは日本語字幕への対応だろう。
スチーム上の記載は無いが、デフォルトで日本語字幕に対応しており、
フォントの荒さや枠からのはみ出し等、多少の気になる部分はあるが
翻訳の質は高く、「キャラクターの性格」と「台詞の言い回し」の
整合性がきちんと取れている。

この翻訳だからこそ思わずクスリと笑ってしまうようなストーリーもあり
ぜひテキストも追って欲しい。

ボリューム比で考えると、
定価の$9.99はカードに対応していることを差し引いても
妥当かやや割高な感がある。購入はセールを待ちたい。
（2014/6/21）

10443227.review:
If you like The Legend of Zelda then you will like this, as it's basically one big homage to the 2D Zelda games. It might be shorter than your usual Zelda game, but in return it gives a lot of brilliantly designed puzzles that genuinely makes you use your brain without relying on crazy-point-and-click logic. The combat isn't as good as in Zelda though, but it's decent enough to not be annoying, and the puzzles is the main meat of this game anyways. The artstyle and characters are also very enjoyable, mixing the best elements of Wind Waker with A Link To The Past vizually and having a colorful gallery of amusing enemies to fight, with a lot of fun references to the Zelda series scattered around for good measure. The music is also good, but not as memorable or brilliant as in the game it's based on, but it's cool still.

All in all, if you don't mind the game being a bit on the short side it's a great buy for any Zelda and/or puzzle fan.

10419045.review:
On the surface Ittle Dew looks like a Zelda clone. Playing as a blonde in a green tunic with a sword (or stick), stuck on an island with a flying friend and top down gameplay doesn't help make it not look like a Zelda clone. That's the flavor of the game. Is it Zelda? No, but it'll do (Ittle Do). This game is slightly different than a Zelda clone because it is a push block puzzle game with a few enemies and deviations from push block puzzles. 

There are a few items and you start with a stick that you can use to light on fire, then melt ice blocks, set off bombs and so on. Eventually you'll move to a flaming sword to do what a flaming stick can, a magical teleportation wand that allows you to set a block, use the wand and have the enemy or object appear where you set the block. Finally, you'll get an ice wand to freeze enemies, blocks, put out fire and even make walls reflect projectiles like your teleportation staff. You can tell a lot of work went into making the items as not just items to solve puzzles, but combat items as well. You can use the teleporation block to set a block under you, step off and if an enemy is on it, the enemy will fly off screen. You can set a block, push it onto spikes, then use the teleportation wand to teleport the enemy into the block on the spikes, killing them that way. Even though it is disguised as Zelda, I feel like the game could have been made in RPG Maker.

All of the items and weapons are bound to buttons on the X-Box controller which is nice, you can use everything at once without having to visit a menu. There are no deaths in this game, so much as there are room restarts. When you die, you just reset whatever room you were in with full health. Rooms including sections of the overworld map. There is no consequence, making it a very easy for kids game. Each room has a hint sign or two and if you need even more help, you can hit the left button to have your fluttering fox friend give you a hint. There is even a nice little map too showing you where treasures and doors are (unlocked and locked).

This is an enjoyable game even if its quick and simple when compared to Zelda. There is a good diverse array of enemies with different ways to take them out. The art style is charming, there is plenty of exploration and a slightly open world go where you want feel. The art style, happy nature, hints and ease of puzzles makes me feel this game is better for kids. Give it a go, its fun for a few brief hours until you complete it in one or two sittings. The game is so brief, there are achievements for beating it under 3 hours and completing it under 15 minutes.

Ittle Dew is a good stepping stone for this developer to make a grander Zelda like game.

10418658.review:
If you grew up in the 80s or early 90s you probably remember the classic exploring adventure games, such as Zelda.    In these games you always played an hero off to find adventure, find treasure and save the world (usually in that order but reverse priority).   To do so, you usually had to solve puzzles and fight plent of bad guys.

Enter Ittle Dew, keen on adventure and treasure, but not so much the saving the world stuff, she is finds herself stranded on an Island, with the only chance of leaving involving getting (i.e. stealing) an artifact from a castle for the shopkeeper.

Along the way you must get (i.e. once again steal) at least two of three magic weapons with the help of the same shopkeeper (who gladly takes your cash for the favor) to solve the puzzles of the castle and surrounding area.

This is a great game that doesn't take itself seriously, but is great for serious players.   You can speed run or play for completion.  There are shortcuts for those willing to do more challanging puzzles, and even alternative ways to solve the puzzles, all while Ittle's sarcastic attitude, her potion-holic assistant "tippsy" and a cast of quite insane villians keep you amused. 

If you expect your games to be serious and realistic, maybe you should look elsewhere, but if you like difficult puzzles and timeless classic-style gameplay, all wrapped up into a tribute to the adventure games of old, then this is definately the game for you.

10382922.review:
A fun little game with pleasant cartoony graphics. It has a strong focus on puzzles which you solve by pushing blocks onto switches and killing enemies. The game in general is somewhat reminiscent of Zelda. The puzzles are challenging but not enough to be frustrating. The game is pretty short and took me about 3 hours to finish, including a tiny bit of sidetracking. It took around an extra 2 to actually complete every puzzle/area. 

I do have some problems with the game however, the boss fights felt out of place and I didn't enjoy them. I was also frustrated with the controls, the game uses the arrow keys as well as A,S,Z,X which in my opinion was an extremely awkward choice of keys, I frequently confused each of the keys despite playing the game for hours. 

FInally, while I enjoyed the solving the puzzles required to beat the main game, I found some of the outside puzzles very annoying to solve, there are a lot of things that the game doesn't explain to you, like the fact that you can bounce portals and ice off of frozen walls, things like this end up being part of how you are meant to solve the puzzles so if you don't know about these things these kind of puzzles can be very difficult to complete. 

Overall, I enjoyed the game and the main story has just the right difficulty level for people who people who are decent at puzzle games. The puzzles outside the main story like those in the Master Cave or Compost Crypt seem to be more for seasoned puzzle solvers.  
It's a nice game but I feel that for its short length, it'd be more accurately priced at $5.

10380427.review: Ittle Dew took the retro zelda/alundra puzzle adventure formula and added in a mix of witty parody alchemy and makes it its own. It is not the best in the genre, but certainly worth mentioning and worth the $ value for any gamers. For a retro puzzle adventure gamer, this little gem is a must have. 7.5/10

10352266.review:
//bottom line:
a decent little zelda-like with a strong emphasis on the puzzles; and a nice goofy humor to it.
nothing spectacular, but worth the money.

//details:
game is a send off of zelda, with a goofy, kid-appropriate humor, and a strong emphasis on puzzle sovling. it is somewhat non-linear, and often gives you several possible paths to choose from, so if you get stuck on one puzzle/room you can generally try another instead, which greatly helps with the frustration level.

main problem I have is with the controls, I have owned this game for a while but never played it due to a bug where the left direction was jammed (avatar kept wanting to go left...). once I tried again with a patched version, I found the keys were not rebindable, and there was no tutorial on how to use them. The controls are pretty simple but, but still, give some basic explantion or better yet, let me customize them to what I prefer.

regarding length: I am ~3 hour in as of this review; and am in the process of earning the last of 3 powerups in the game.
based on that and how much of the map I have covered, I am guessing I am around 50+ % of the way thru the main game
this may be a bit short for some folks, but I personally find it comparble to other puzzle/action games such as VVVVVV, portal      1/2, and escape goat 1/2. it is not the best value, but definatly reasonable for this type of game.
it also has a lot of optional/bonus content; including in-game cards for all the NPCs, and a 'master's cave' with more challenging puzzles. so probably extend my estimate by at least another 3 hours or so.

10340253.review:
TL;DR: So, I got this game off humble bundle and wasn't particularly excited to play it. I started it up expecting to hate it after a few minutes and then just let it idle for the cards, but boy was I wrong. This game is really good. Probably among the most fun puzzle game I've played. Easy 8/10. 

So in this game you play as an adventurer. Not much is known about your character aside from the fact that she's totally a girl. I mean, I didn't pay too much attention to the story, but that's basically all I know about it having completed the game.

You're off to get 3 magical items to help you solve progressively more complicated puzzles, a fire sword, a portal wand, and a ice wand thing. Different objects on the screen interact differently (or not at all) with each magical item. Conveniently, a local shopkeeper sells them and you're able to purchase them from him. Only, when you do, you're put into a puzzle series cave where you have to show somewhat of a mastery of the item to get out. 

Some of the puzzles are really solid, making you somewhat frustrated after not getting them within the first 10 tries. Of course, there's also the others that are super obvious and take maybe 1 attempt, 2 if you pressed the wrong button. Good variety and the later stages of the puzzles make you think with portals. 

Combat is pretty dull in the game. Though, admittedly, I totally died to a pancake out of recklessness more than a few times. Valv pls fix. You press x to do the damage, or you can be fancy and try to teleport mobs into spikes or something. 

The controls either weren't given out in the game (I had to press every key on my keyboard to figure out how to use the stick to attack for a while), or I totally didn't pay attention to the tutorial. There is a 2 level tutorial. 

Oh, I forgot to mention, the puzzles vary between push blocks into pressure plates, clear all enemies on the map, light all the things that need lighting, or burn out all the things that shouldn't be on fire. You might think that's pretty lame and hardly fun, but the quickness of the game definitely makes thing way less awful than they would be. Trust me.

Aside from combat, which really isn't even a big deal because the game isn't driven to encourage you to fight everything on the map except in a few area where you need to to open a door, the only real upset with the game is how fast you can complete it. Keep in mind, I had intended to just get all the cards in the game and then back out. I was sucked in and before I knew it, I finished the game. I mean, sure, I didn't 100% it, but I cleared the final boss. I didn't expect to because a certain key item given out at the end led me to believe that there would be some other areas to access, but that wasn't the case. In my first blind run, I finished the game in three and a half hours. I mean, sure, that's actually a pretty reasonable time for a game to take in a campaign mode anyway, but I really really wanted more. I guess that's a good thing, though.

So after getting here this far, you probably know that I'm going to rate this game pretty highly. I would put Antichamber and Portal above this game in terms of similar games that are more fun, but this game isn't too far behind! Easy eight out of ten. I would only dock points for not doing anything groundbreakingly new (which would push it over the top and is basically a requirement to get a 10. Fuck people who give every game 10s), and being exceptionally short. Though, the latter is likely not an issue because this game can be played on your phone.

Oh yes

you heard me

you can play it on your phone. 

I would encourage anyone with even a mild interest in puzzle games to give this one a shot.

10330397.review:
Trust me, Ittle Definitely Dew
As you may be able to tell from the pictures, or from others, it is a adventure puzzle game. Most compare it to The Legend of Zelda (its even in the tags). But don't let that dissuade you from playing; it is anything but a cheap ripoff. 
This game puts you in place of a female adventurer named Ittle Dew, with her potion-aholic companion appropriately named Tippsie, as you crash land on an island. Your main goal is, of course, to find what secrets the island may hold. The game is humorous and cute in its old fashion, often giving you little quips of dialogue here and there. 
One unique thing about the game is the way it handles it puzzles; there are several ways to solve them with your different tools. As you progress through the game, you unlock more tools to help you solve previous puzzles. But you don't need all the tools to solve all the puzzles. If you're up for the challenge, that is.
The game is quircky and fun. A fair length given its price. If you enjoy puzzle games, you'll enjoy this one. Fans of the Zelda series will fall right in.

10162764.review:
Il y a des jeux qui ont l'air très bons et nous décoivent, Ittle Dew est un jeu à l'air moyen mais qui finalement est excellent.

Ce jeu volontairement aux airs de Zelda est avant tout un jeu d'énigmes, avec pas mal d'humour et même des surprises.

Les énigmes reposent sur un sytème à priori très simple utiliser les pouvoirs de 3 objets pour ouvrir l'accès à la salle suivante.
Les 3 objets sont une épée de feu, une baguette de glace et baguette de téléportation.

Une fois ces pouvoirs aquis, on doit les combiner pour avancer. Par exemple, téléporter une bombe, lui mettre le feu avec l'épée, la geler pour pouvoir la faire glisser au travers la pièce...

Au niveau rejouabilité c'est simplement énorme:

-4 moyens de finir le jeu: Avec les 3 objets ou avec la paire d'objets de notre choix.
-2 donjons facultatifs
-des caves d'énigmes dispersées un peu partout sur la carte pour augmenter sa vie ou sa collection de cartes

Une très belle surprise :)

10069651.review: Underrated, in my opinion.  Probably a touch expensive at full price, but any given sale would bring it down to a decent bang for your buck even if you only shoot for one playthrough rather than opting to go the full nine with all the self-challenges presented in the achievements.  Irreverent humor that pokes a lot fun at the genre and its roots while staying thematic and true to character.  I loved the characters and art, I enjoyed the puzzles -- though some were a bit obtuse or required quick mechanical handling of the controls that sometimes left something to be desired (small facing and hitbox issues here and there detracted from what was otherwise a very apt puzzle/combat control system, and the hint system was fairly frequently either overly helpful or completely useless).  Overall, I would heartily recommend the game to any fan of the genre, so long as they can handle a few juvenile laughs and a couple minor shortcomings.

9821588.review:
What can be said about Ittle Dew? It apes games like the Legend of Zelda, all the while parodying them. Everything from dungeon puzzles to old men in caves are used in the comic arsenal. The majority of the time the humour is spot on but occasionally a joke fails to land.

The gameplay is pretty solid for the most part, while in combat it can feel a little slow to respond, but thankfully combat is generally used as a way to solve a puzzle. Most of the puzzles are pretty simple, with exception of the "expert route's" you find scattered (these are shortcuts but with puzzles that are much much more difficult.

My main issue with the game is it's length, in that it's completely feasible to complete the game in just under half a day.

I would recommend this game if it's on sale for £4 or less, it's just too short to pay more.

9818344.review: This odd little indie game is both deceptively short and deceptively long. While the game itself can be beaten very quickly (there's an achievement for managing it in under 15 minutes), there are several routes you can take, of varying length. In short, this is a top-down game (similar to the oldschool Zelda games in terms of control), with a heavy emphasis on humor and parody, and there are different ways around puzzles depending on which items you buy. There are three items, and you can beat the game with any two of them. This is a game meant to be replayed several times, and each time should put a new twist on the same puzzles. Recommended for puzzle fans, or someone looking for a good change of pace for a little while.
