9748145.review:
Traditional Zelda is a style of gameplay that is near and dear to many people. The top down adventure makes for some creative puzzle situations and hugely detailed maps. After many years of tinkering with the formula, Nintendo is finally returning to their heritage with The Legend of Zelda: A Link Between Worlds.

What are gamers to do in the meantime, though? If one is not a fan of the 3D games or the DS titles, what kind of game will fill the void? Enter Ittle Dew, a top down adventure game from indie dev Ludosity. What the game lacks in innovative puzzle and world design, it more than makes up for with charm and game feel.

The plotline for Ittle Dew is incredibly simple. Your character washes up on the shore of an island and wants to get off. The caretaker of a shop will build you a raft as long as you go through some dungeons he has set up. You also need to pay him for the items he sells, so there is a main hub dungeon that will let you accrue some cash.

This is probably the weakest element of the game. While the original Zelda game did not really possess a story of any kind, forgoing a narrative in today’s age is a curious decision. One can personally believe that gameplay speaks above all else, but without a strong desire to continue, some gamers may not even be bother to check Ittle Dew out.

Thankfully, the puzzle designs in Ittle Dew are fairly strong. Stripping down the Zelda formula to its basics, Ittle Dew gives players very limited commands to deal with. Controls are essentially walking with the joystick, the four face buttons used for specific items and two shoulders buttons for a map and hint screen.

The hint screen is very nicely done, too. Instead of spelling out solutions or talking in cryptic riddles, the game uses the humorous character of Tippsie to lightly insult the player while giving some key hints. Things like, “You’ll only need your fire sword for this room,” are better tests of skill than detailing exactly where to swing your item.

The specific items collected are a teleport rod, a fire sword and an ice rod. In an interesting twist, there is no proper order of progression in the game. The best aspect of is how non-linear the design is. Upon completing the journey, I was under the belief that any player would have to acquire all three of the weapons to finish their quest. That actually isn’t the case. Some of the dungeons even have shortcuts direct to the boss rooms.

Along with shortcuts and paths for skipping items, the game also has hidden dungeons for collecting extra health and cards. The cards don’t really offer any purpose to the game, but their rooms have some insidiously obtuse puzzle designs. I was stumped in one room for a solid 20 minutes before stumbling upon the answer.

When you are transported to any dungeon for a specific item, you only need your wits to get through. No puzzles require another objects or skills you do not possess. This alleviates a lot of frustration from the proceedings.

There really isn’t much in the way of challenge, however. If you die, the game simply restarts you in the exact same room with full health. Other than how the sword’s arc doesn’t fully surround your character, the only time one will get annoyed is when they cannot solve a puzzle quickly.

A good mention must go to the writing behind Ittle Dew. Everything is very self-referential and parody laden. Genre tropes like collecting hearts and destroying pots all make some kind of appearance. Even the nonsensical nature of enemy placement gets mentioned for being so pointless.

Your main character revels in eating hearts and even wishes to just smack things around. The bosses utter some ridiculously incomprehensible catch phrases and then admit to not even knowing what they were talking about. One cannot help but crack a smile while playing.

Even the ending is funny. While a rather obvious plot twist occurs, when the final battle comes to a close, the game pokes fun at how most final bosses just kind of give up or don’t take a more obvious approach.

Sadly, while Ittle Dew might be great at questioning why adventure games follow specific mechanics, the game really does nothing to spice them up. One shouldn’t be displeased with a fairly high quality Zelda-
like game, but a lack of innovation really does hurt the final product.

There are some texture designs on the world map that are misleading, as well. For the most part, you cannot walk behind any of the trees in the game. Some of the hidden dungeons are behind them, though. Enemies also disappear behind the trees and are completely invisible to the player.

For that matter, the world map doesn’t really serve any purpose other than to move you from point A to point B. Hiding extraneous items behind puzzles is a great incentive for replay value, but giving players some other reason to explore would go a long way to creating a believable world.

There is a bonus dungeon hidden in the fields. This acts as the penultimate test of your skills, requiring every item in the game to fully complete. There are 12 rooms and each one gets progressively more challenging in skill. This serves as a nice little bonus to an otherwise very short game.

To sum everything up, while Ittle Dew might not be the second coming of adventure gaming or a masterpiece of epic proportions, the game provides plenty of wit and humor along with some decently mind bending puzzles. The game also controls nicely.

For $14, one could do much worse. Ludosity certainly does not get points for creativity, but their craftsmanship is noble. This game may not be Zelda, but Ittle Dew. (7/10)

9406686.review:
Firstly, I just want to say that I don’t think that Ittle Dew is a 2D Zelda rip-off. Ittle Dew is a charming and artistically beautiful game that simply makes fun of 2D Zelda games and I have got to say, this kind of works.

On the other hand, this game brings nothing new to the table but it wasn’t a disadvantage for me, I’ve had fun while playing it, puzzle sections can be difficult though , sometimes I had to take a brake and approach this game differently. I liked it, it was somewhat enjoyable for me, especially during the dialogue sections, they were funny and very well written.

An equally significant aspect of the game was its art style, It was a pleasure looking at the vibrant art during my playthrough which made this game one of the best presented block puzzle game ever.

Despite the great art style and clever writing, this game did had some problems, for ex. its length, I was able to beat this game in less than 4 hours, I know it might turn some people off but I have realized that in some cases this is not a disadvantage but in this case, well, it was but one of the recent examples where the short game can be successful is the game called Gone Home made by The Fullbright Company which could be completed in 2 hours but Gone Home is a completely different game and again in Ittle Dew, It just wasn’t enough, to be honest I wanted more.

In the end, Ittle Dew is an adorable block puzzle game, with a decent gameplay and a crafty writing. For this price, you won’t be disappointed, just don’t expect it to be a Zelda clone because it pretty much makes fun of this game which sometimes can be very entertaining.

9326941.review:
Ittle Dew is an action-adventure game heavily inspired by the Zelda games with heavy emphasis on replayability and speed-running. Mechanically, Ittle Dew works just about as well as you'd expect. You can walk around, hit enemies, but the real fun comes from the various puzzles. Like a Zelda game, Ittle Dew has an assortment of items that you'll utilize to solve puzzles. However, unlike a Zelda game, where you'll usually find yourself with 7-8 unique items, Ittle Dew only has. This isn't a major issue, for two reasons. Ittle Dew is a shorter game than Zelda games, and two the way that item's works together creates a large amount of replayabilty, due the game's design allowing for puzzles to be solved in multiple different ways. Ittle Dew's three items are a fire sword, which should be fairly self-explanatory, you hit things and light them on fire, a Portal Wand, which allows you to create blocks and teleport objects around and a Ice Wand which allows you to freeze objects. A large portion of the games puzzles are solvable in multiple different ways using any number of the game's items. Even beating the game only requires 2/3 of the items, this encourages exploration in the game world and experimentation with the game's mechanics as you figure out how to get to the end with a limited toolset, and I found doing so to be very compelling. There is also a fair amount of optional content, from hidden collectibles that require optional puzzles to be found, to a couple of optional dungeons. Competetive players will also enjoy trying to figure out optimal routes through the game in order to beat the game quickly.
While I can prise Ittle Dew puzzle solving mechanics and overall design, it's not a perfect game. There's some combat throughout Ittle Dew, and frankly it's not very fun. More often than not, I found that having to kill the enemies in a room detracted from the fun puzzles that I should be solving in the room. There's also bosses, but they're mostly one-trick ponies. You'll figure out how to defeat them quite quickly, and they rarely pose a threat. The combat is a minor part of the game, but I can't help but think it could of been more deeply intergrated into the best parts of the game, the puzzle solving.

9098390.review:
После неожиданной русификации [b] Ittle Dew [/b], чему я был приятно удивлён, я решил написать рекомендацию на неё, поскольку понимание сюжета на родном языке для меня является одним из ключевых особенностей при покупке игры.

Ittle Dew - это такая приключенческая инди головоломка, рассказывающая историю потерпевших корабле... вернее плотокрушение босоногой девочки приключенца Итл Дью и её спутницы Типпси на острове полном загадок, головоломок и сокровищ. Игра состоит из множества комнат. Чтоб перейти из одной в другую, часто нужно решить головоломку: убить всех врагов, нажать на все кнопки одновременно, потушить огонь или зажечь его. Вам придётся передвигать камни, ломать ледяные глыбы или толкать их по шипам, телепортировать врагов и себя, активировать кристаллы и другое. На пути девочки встречаются разнообразные противники, начиная от некоего подобия утконоса, заканчивая переодетыми в животных стражников. Помогать прохождению будут волшебные предметы - Меч Огня, Посох Льда и Посох Порталов. Причём пройти игру можно как используя все 3 предмета, так и два любых на выбор (и на этом завязаны достижения). Также присутствует мировой рейтинг скоростного прохождения для любителей speedrun'а. Ну а для любителей поразмышлять есть необязательная Гробница Мастеров, где вам нужно проявить недюжую смекалку (признаюсь, моей не хватило, подглядывал в интернете). 

Игра не без юмора, и достаточно неплохого я вам скажу. Антиправило пяти секунд, мнимая слабость утконосов, коллекционные карточки, встречи с противниками, финальный босс... и прочее.

Симпатичная рисованная графика, музыка, головоломки, юмор, атмосфера. Я бы повысил рейтинг на Metacritic эдак до 75 баллов, но к сожалению это не в моих силах. Поэтому я просто скажу: "Рекомендую".

9047621.review:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Lfa8EJ9MA2w
It may look and feel like The Legend of Zelda, but this is not your average Hyrulean adventure. What sets Ittle Dew apart from Nintendo's classic franchise are a willingness to make fun of itself and extremely streamlined gameplay. It's so streamlined, in fact, that you can easily beat the game in only a handful of hours. There is a deck of character cards scattered throughout the world that could potentially extend your play time, but they aren't very rewarding to collect. Plus if you wait until you are fully equipped, many of these optional puzzles are easier than they were intended to be. Speaking of equipment, Ittle Dew's arsenal would leave Link green with envy. The portal wand especially introduces some very unique puzzles that elevate the game above standard-fare LoZ block pushing and flip switching. There's still plenty of that, but the game is always aware of its source material and freely pokes fun of it. The first time I picked a heart up off the ground, I nearly fell out of my chair laughing. From the irreverent sense of humor to the squiggly hand drawn graphics, Ittle Dew is a charming game that holds its own against its apparent competitor.

8853171.review:
Ittle Dew

"Зельда для нищих"

Так бы сказал наверное каждый, кто знаком с франшизой, на первый взгляд это действительно так. Но так ли это на самом деле - решать вам.

Собственно Ittle Dew - это замечательная, внешне очень похожая на портативные Зелды, инди-адвенчура с красивой графикой и расслабляющим геймплеем. И игра именно этой самой расслабленностью и отличается от Зельды. Напряженные сражения с огромными боссами, множество разных типов противников, бесконечные скитания по подземельям, а также большое множество разных предметов - всего этого в Ittle Dew нет. Но не спешите воспринимать все вышеперечисленнное как минусы игры, напротив, скорее все это и является несомненными плюсами.

Куча головоломок с передвижением блоков при помощи разных предметов(огненный меч, палка-телепорталка, ледяной посох), наполненных разного вида противниками, которые к сожалению не очень разнообразны, но крайне милы, отличнейшее визуальное оформление, анимация, довольно неплохая музыка и забавные ненавязчивые диалоги, из всего этого, в совокупности и получается Ittle Dew. Даже не верится что с помощью каких-то трех предметов можно сделать настолько разнообразные уровни. Что касается косяков игры, для меня навереное это нехватка динамики, но это придирки. Короче. Если вы являетесь большим любителем головоломок или фанатом Зельд, то эта игра однозначно для вас, а если нет, то попробуйте пощупать игру, вполне возможно что именно она привьет любовь к подобным играм.

Очень и очень хорошо.
7,5/10

8815049.review: This was an enjoyable dungeon puzzle type game. You go through dungeons mostly solving puzzles, but there is a combat element to the game also. The combat is pretty basic, but you can freeze and teleport enemies in addition to slashing them with your sword. The puzzles are nicely balanced. Nothing was too hard to feel like giving up on and nothing was too easy to get bored on. The only thing I didn't like was the optional Master Cave dungeon. You basically needed a walkthrough to get through most of these. The solution to a lot of the puzzles require doing things that you never did during the main game, but are expected to know about somehow in this dungeon. A few of the puzzles also require fast reflexes instead of just puzzle solving like the rest of the game. It just all felt out of place to me. Overall though, the game was very enjoyable and I would recommend to anyone that likes the puzzle solving in something like The Legend of Zelda games. You can do mostly everything (minus the achievements) in about 7 hours, depending on how quickly you can figure out the puzzles.

Quand l'on voit les combinaisons des capacités des 3 objets réunis dans une seule énigme, je me dis que les créateurs de ce jeu ne sont pas des amateurs.

8474525.review:
To address the elephant in the room: yes, this is very much like the classic Legend of Zelda games.  However, I would have to disagree with some other reviewers that this game is a rip-off of the Zelda series.

Surprisingly, I found quite a few of the puzzles to be more challenging than I've found in Zelda games (and yes, I remember the water temple in OoT.)  The developers did an excellent job of creating some difficult puzzles which take all of the available tools to solve (especially in the optional Master Cave.)  The interaction between the freezing rod and the portal rod was especially ingenious.  Plus, the game itself is quite tongue-in-cheek, which keeps it pretty lighthearted.  I was pleased to see the random commentary when walking up to some random objects throughout the game.

I thoroughly enjoy games that make me think, and this game definitely accomplished that.  Additionally, I found Ittle Dew to have decent replay value due to the added challenge of trying to complete the game with varying combinations of the tools (rather than all of them.)

In the end, if you enjoy puzzle-heavy games in the same vein as classic Legend of Zelda (and have a sense of humor), then Ittle Dew is worth the purchase.

7935362.review:
The game took about 3 hours to complete my first run through, but it will get faster with experience, and there are even achievements for completing the game within 15 minutes as well as doing it with 3 combinations of only 2 of the 3 items.

The game can be a bit frustrating at times, especially the final boss which was very little puzzle and a boatload of enemies that went on for far too long. The rest of the game on the other hand, was almost made up entirely of puzzles revolving around 3 items. A flaming sword, an ice wand, and a teleportation wand. The items can actually be aquired in any order if you know what you are doing, but it does a decent job of explaining each individually. By the end of the game, you have to use all of these items in conjuction with eachother. You can drop a teleportation block, freeze it, kick it across a spike pit, and then freeze the wall to shoot a teleportation beam that bounces back and hits yourself, sending you to where the frozen block landed. Now that probably sounds really complicated, but the way you are gradually led into single items and then combinations of two or all 3, you really get the hang of it by the end.

All of the rooms reset every time you go in except doors that have unlocked, so this cancels any possibility of brining things between the rooms, which makes it easier to work out the puzzles. The levels are very well designed. I felt that it was always introducing new mechanics, concepts, and ways to use the items together. I actually never had a single instance where I got stuck to where I couldn't get out of a certain spot. Although if that were to happen, there is a reset room in the pause menu. There are no consumable items of any kind, not even potions. I feel as if carryable items aside from the sword and two wands would complicate the puzzles and the game, so it is great that they aren't there. The checkpoint system is great in my opinion. If you die, you come back in just as you entered the room, with no penalties of any kind. It's really not an RPG, its more of a sliding block and combat puzzle adventure, it is only really styled after Zelda visually and thematically.

I encountered only a single glitch, and it was in the final boss stage. An enemy froze in its dying animation and stayed in place for a minute or so.

Overall I think this is a quirky, enjoyable, and decently challenging puzzle game, with tons of references to zelda, and a cute/unique art style. The game felt a little unfinished in a few areas. There didn't seem to be any music at all while the conversation with the final boss was going on, and it just wasn't as fleshed out as it could have been. It's not a must-play title by any means, but it will challenge you and give you a few good laughs. The puzzles can seem daunting or even impossible at times, but I urge you to keep at it. A bit of trial and error, and you'll figure them out. If you aren't willing to take a minute and think about things, you might not have such a great time...

7897389.review:
2Dゼルダ風の謎解きをゲーム全編にわたって行うゲーム。
戦闘要素もあるがオマケ程度、基本的には謎解きだけのゲームと考えて良い。ゲームとしての広がりが無く、ただ小さくまとまったゲームと言う印象。

道を遮る石を押して通れるようにする、木の枝に火を付けて燭台を灯す、爆弾に火を付けて壁を爆破して進む、などのいわゆる2Dゼルダ風の謎解きを行って進んで行く。
逆にそれ以外の要素は非常に薄い。途中で数個の謎解き用のアイテムを入手したり、HPを上げる隠し要素を探したりボス戦があったりと、一応プレイのバリエーションを広げようとする工夫はして
ある。しかし、やはりゲームプレイの大半謎解きであり、それ以外を期待すべきでは無い。

このゲームの中身を単純化すれば、「ある部屋には入り口と出口があり、その間に移動を妨げる仕掛けがある、この仕掛けを解いて出口に辿り着く方法を考える。」これを複数の部屋で繰り返すだけだと言える。その他の要素はこの謎解きの合間の時間稼ぎにしかなっていない。
自分がこのゲームを好きになれない理由としては二点ある。
一つは単純に、このゼルダ風謎解きそのものがあまり好きでないと言う点。
もう一つは、ゼルダ風謎解きに特化したゲームならばせめてもっときちんと特化して欲しかったと言う点。つまり、演出としてもあまり機能しているとは思えないその他の要素はいっそ排除して、謎解きだけをひたすら行うパズルゲームにしてあった方が良かったのではないかと言う事。
半端に広いマップで次に進む場所を探すだとか、進んでる途中で敵と戦ってHPが削られるだとか、入手してないアイテムが必要な謎解きを必死に解こうとしてしまうだとか、そう言う要素は必要無かったと思う。

ゲーム全体としてみれば特に大きな欠点があるタイトルでは無い。むしろ内容に対して丁寧に作られてるとは思う。ただゲームとしての中身があまりにも小さすぎその小さな中身を表現するにはゲームとして無駄が多すぎるのでは無いかと思う。
いっそ小さいなりに無駄な要素を削るか、逆に謎解き要素がアクセントになるくらい他の要素もしっかり作るかして欲しかった。

7876428.review:
A wonderful homage to the Zelda franchise. Ittle Dew features an amazing amount of well thought and tricky puzzles. A huge amount of time and love went into crafting and polishing this game.

Side note: Ittle Dew was actually submitted as an idea to Nintendo as a Zelda spinoff, but they turned it down. Which is really too bad for them as this would have fit in with any of the Wind Waker style of Zelda games.

Probably for the best really, a lot of the charm of Ittle Dew comes from the aesthetic as a Zelda parody, from poking fun at the goofy statues to the over the top silly monsters.

Really, the only thing I'd want out of Ittle Dew is a little more content, your first playthrough will top out at 90 to 150 minutes of play. However, there are multiple ways to finish the game, which can lead to a lot of replay value.

But that said, Ittle Dew is very much worth your time and money if you are a fan of puzzle games.

Thanks.

This is a delightfully animated (heavy) puzzle (light) action game. The video actually does a great job of showing what the game is like to play, so if you like the look, get it. I personally really enjoyed the gameplay, and thought the art style and humour was excellent. I think the gameplay is actually better than that in every other game in this genre (zelda clone) that Ive played because its been designed to lower frustration, repetition and maximise enjoyment (eg dying costs nothing, no backtracking required ever, hints) while still retaining challenge.

The only caveat I can give is that its better played with a gamepad, and the gamepad support is broken (you need to remap all gamepad controls from gamepad 0 to gamepad 1, and you need to remap the second hori and vert directions everytime you play, else the controls act like you are continually pushing UP - super annoying - these bugs are months old and havent been patched, so I wouldnt expect them to be now). That said, its a easily remedied minor gripe and a small impediment to this delightful game.

7560042.review:
Ittle Dew is an action-adventure game that is trying very hard to be a 2D Zelda game, and actually, it succeeds for the most part. Your goal is to explore the castle and use the riches you find to enter other dungeons and find tools that help you progress farther in the castle.

This game has two key strengths. The first is that the items are very interesting, and they each combine in interesting ways. The second is that this game has amazing replay value. You get three items, and you can use all three to win, but you only need two. For a challenge, try beating the game with each combination of two weapons. This game is also built for speed-running, and it will take a lot of planning to figure out how to get the speed run achievements.

I'd say this game's main weakness is the bosses. It's a big difficulty spike, and the method for defeating them is never straightforward. The hints help a lot, but the battles can still be tough even when you know what to do. That leads to the other weakness: the controls. They're not terrible, and you'll get used to them as you play, but there were too many times when I died in combat because I wasn't moving the way I wanted to, and many enemies aren't knocked back when hit.

A few other things to mention: the puzzles can get pretty tough, the death penalty is that you have to restart the room at full health (which isn't even a penalty most of the time), and the game has little story, but the humor was a lot better than I had expected from the previews. Also, the first playthrough will last around 3-5 hours.

So, despite this game's rather stupid name, I enjoyed it, and I'd say it's worth picking up if you enjoy Zelda-style games (try out the 2D Zeldas first if you're not familiar with them). I'd wait to pick it up at half price, though.

7467927.review:
Really fun and challenging puzzle-adventure game in the style of 2D Zelda with a quirky sense of sarcastic humor and non-sequitur plot twists.

If you've ever played Link's Awakening and cursed at the Eagle's Tower puzzle where you had to demolish the pillars using the metal ball, this game is full of problems exactly like that and is very satisfying to overcome.  If you don't know what that is, why aren't you off playing that right now?

It also has some replay value in the alternative paths you can take to reach the final boss.  At first glance you will think every item is necessary and only obtainable in a fixed order, but with a little creativity taught over the course of playing you will realize any two are sufficient to finish and can be obtained out of order.  Taking these routes also requires solving optional puzzles which are more difficult than the default route.

If you're a true sadomasochist (or chive completionist) you can try your hand at the Master Dungeon which is full of all the puzzles the devs had the sense not to put in the main quest.  Sadly the boss of this dungeon is the low point of the game as it requires brute force button mashing and luck instead of skill and ingenuity.

If you like 2D Zelda games then you need this game. It has great humour, a lovely art style, the gameplay is great and the puzzles are satisfying. I can't recommend this enough. At the time or writing I've only played it for 40 minutes and I'm loving it.

This is one of the games that has sold me on Steam Big Picture Mode. It's as good a quality, if not a little higher than the 2D Zelda games Nintendo offers. We've already got a decent number of good shooters and action games that work well in Big Picture Mode, it's nice to see something that you'd normally only get from Nintendo.

If you don't want to pay full price, it occasionally appears in bundles and goes on sale but it is definitely worth the full £6.99. Ittle Dew is funny, full of charm and Nintendo should be cursing themselves for not locking it down as an exclusive. I recommend this game 100%.

3452533.review:
Although pitched as a Zelda parody, dismissing Ittle Dew as such would be doing it a disservice. While the delightful art style and fantastic soundtrack both pay homage to the classic series, the similarities in actual gameplay are rather cursory and it turns out that's a good thing.

The emphasis here is entirely on the puzzles, more specifically, block puzzles. You'll spend nearly your entire stay on the island pushing, freezing, and teleporting blocks and enemies around, flipping switches and ultimately opening a ton of chests and doors on your quest for treasure. As the sole focus of the adventure the quality of the puzzles is paramount, and fortunately they happen to be supremely well designed and satisfying to solve, rarely crossing the line into overly hard nor easy. They provide an entertaining challenge as well as a bit of replayability with several different paths available for completing the game, something that's rarely seen in this genre.

All of this combined with the clever boss fights, tongue in cheek humor, and outstanding presentation add up to a very short but (technical hiccups aside) immensely enjoyable game from start to finish. Don't make the mistake of taking Ittle Dew at face value, for it has more than enough heart to breakaway from it's inspiration, and should not be missed!

539516.review:
[Spoiler-Free Review]

Sometimes a game's influences are all the review you need.

To put it succinctly, Ittle Dew is Indie Zelda and exactly the type of game development you want to be supporting: clever, charismatic, entertaining, and absolutely stunning. The developers clearly demonstrate competence here; If this was the latest iteration in Nintendo's franchise, you'd never guess it was made by anyone else - it's that good.

The only contentious aspect for me is the game's length. It's true I finished it in a single sitting, but I was also engaged with the characters and world in a way that made it difficult to put down. I hope the devs continue with the series and create a full-scale experience with their next game - their talents demand it!

Ittle Dew is excellent. Don't sit on the fence with this one.

I don't think I've ever seen a game that lived up to its name so perfectly. It's not amazing, the gameplay is incredibly shallow*, and if you've ever played a top-down Zelda title you'll probably get the "finish in under 3 hours" achievement easily. But on the other hand, the animation's stellar, the music... I've forgotten the music, actually, and some of the jokes had me cracking a smile. It is absolutely a middle-of-the-road game. It'll do.

* Yes, there are the 'challenges' you can take on, like the cave full of bastard-hard puzzles, or beating the game with only two items instead of 3, or speedrunning it. 5652668.review:
謎解き型パズル＆見下ろし型アクションなゲーム。
ナンセンスな世界観の島でどう見ても少年にしか見えない冒険者Ittleちゃんが謎の城で謎の支配者が用意した罠や頭のおかしい兵士と戦いつつお宝を探して冒険するというお話。

パズルは押せるが引けないブロックを上手く動かしてスイッチに乗せるタイプのアレ。それ以外もあるが難解なのはおおむねこのタイプ。
1周15分で終わるので時間のない人におすすめ。というのは大嘘ですが、問題の数自体は初見で5時間もあればフルコンプできる程度。
ボリューム満点とはいえないが不満のない程度には充実してるし、問題の質もなかなかだと思う。特にクリア後の隠しマップの問題は大変難解で面白かった。
また、クリア時間短縮のためには3つある攻略用アイテムの取得を2つに絞ることになるので、2周目以降もいくつかのパターンの解法を楽しめる。

一方アクション要素は正直面白くないのであまり期待しないほうがいい。裏ボス戦は二度とやりたくない。
またマップと問題の配置は固定なのでタイムアタックは結局のところ早解きなどではなく覚えゲーであることも一応注意が必要かも。
あくまで限られた問題を解くだけのパズルゲーと認識しておけば裏切られることもないかと。

ともあれ価格も含めてインディーらしいインディーということで気軽におすすめできる作品。
パズルゲー好きには特におすすめ。15分クリアの実績を目指してがんばりましょう。

270767.review:
This is a small puzzle game where you traverse a few dungeons with a bunch of different mechanics and items that define what techniques and actions you can use to solve them. It took me less than 3 hours to finish it and get a majority of cards and other things, and I’ve spent over an hour after that finishing the collection. Haven’t decided if I should take the rest of the achievements yet or not, could be a fun challenge though. All in all I’ve spent about 5 hours on it and there’s still things for me to do, but mostly in the interest of completing the game without all weapons unlocked or speedrunning.

I have to say that its quite funny written, the characters and how they behave make fun of retro concepts, like eating hearts that fall on the ground. It doesn’t take itself very serious, which fits nicely into everything else.

So, gameplay! You solve puzzles by either hitting things, putting things on plates or killing things. Basically, if you have no items, you are limited to pushing blocks and finding fireplaces to light your stick on fire. But if you have a firesword you don’t need to find fireplaces, and if you have the icestaff and the firesword you can freeze blocks and then shatter them with your firesword. If you have the portal wand, you can solve even more puzzles, etc. Not only that, you can combine most of the tools in very, very interesting ways that wasn’t expected at all by me.

This works very well and the puzzles range from crazy obvious to "bweh?” making you feel very stupid when you don’t get them, and extremely clever when you finally do. In many cases you can leave it for later.

Every dungeon have a boss and they are ok most of the time. Personally I really disliked the last boss and the boss in the master dungeon (which were the only place where I eventually looked for help in solving the rooms). The last boss being annoying and the master dungeon boss being both hard and showing a lot of gameplay fallacies I dislike in 2D top-down games. Still the game is about solving puzzles first and the bosses come as a break that can be quite welcome.

It’s super pretty and animated in a way that completely fits the style. It very simply borrows a lot from Zelda games in how the graphics look, but have its own way of drawing it, which makes it more of a homage.

Anyway, if you like puzzle games and solving rooms zelda-style, get it!
If you want something more action-heavy, then you should probably look elsewhere.

Have a good day! :)

740988.review:
Take the original Legend of Zelda's level design and add a lot of clever puzzles and a sprinkling of humor and you have "iTTLE DEW." No, this is not a Zelda-like RPG. And, no, it does not try to be a Zelda-like RPG. Putting the graphics aside, this is it's own unique game. 

The puzzles are worth the price of admission alone. They consist of pushing blocks, planting bombs, and and using your unique items to help you progress. Some of these puzzles can be quite challenging. One of the really clever things about this game is that some puzzles can be completed in different ways by using a different combination of your items. It makes for a lot of "ah ha" moments. There is also a real satisfaction in walking into a room that may seem utterly impossible only to discover the solution after reasoning things out. 

There are enemies to fight, akin to Zelda, but they serve more to enhance the puzzle mechanic rather than offer an action spin. With that said, it does mix things up in the puzzle department and there are collectables that can be picked up for your efforts. 

The only gripe i have with the game is that it is painfully short. It can be completed in a matter of minutes for more intelligent gamers out there; there is even an achievement for it. The average gamer will be able to experience most of what the game has to offer in two to three hours. The game does offer extras in terms of collectables that can be sought for completionists and a end game dungeon to really challenge your puzzle solving acumen. This can extend the game time some but over all it does leave you wanting more.

这是通关的第46个steam游戏了。
游戏是类似2d版塞尔达那样的动作解谜游戏，总体来说是个推箱子游戏了。流程很短，只有一个城堡三个道具区域，以及之间的过道，另外还有一个大师级试炼洞穴。
游戏本身11国语言无中文，对游玩没什么障碍，打上繁体中文包后游戏里的一些幽默对话一些梗看的明白了，游戏也多了一点乐趣，比如吐槽，为什么石头里也能掉出心来。
游戏里能获得三样道具，第一个火刀，能打碎冰块以及点燃木头堆；第二个传送杖，能制造一个方块，并且把炸弹啊，敌人啊什么的传送过去；第三个冰杖，能冻住敌人和炸弹方块什么的。 三样道具的获得流程完全是系统定死的，虽然说要花金币买，但是到时候你真的只能获得那么多金币。每次买一个道具，就会传送到一个道具区域，只能使用这个道具来破关，之后继续主线的城堡。
所以有时候有的谜题解不开了，千万不要卡死在这里，有时候真的只需获得新的道具，解起来不要太轻松。记得获得火刀后第一个过道里，已经获得了其他的卡片，只有一个2×2的4个冰块的谜题，怎么也解不了这题。后来发现，只要获得了传送杖后，这个谜题是分分钟的事，可怜当时我虚耗了半个小时在这里。
游戏作为塞尔达类型的，对操控性有一定的要求，有的机关连续敲几个立方体，慢了就过不去，另外还要打怪打boss的，虽然只需要按LB就能立刻知道打法攻略。。。
最后才发现，这游戏名字是ittle dew，不是little

39520914.review:
В целом : 
 Обаятельная игра на стыке жанров приключение-головоломка, полна шуток, секретов и вариантов прохождения.

Положительное:
+ Юмор, жизнелюбие, общее позитивное настроение повествования, то самое *Ittle Dew* - *так сойдет*.
+ Приятный, мягкий, современный (модный, стильный, молодежный, кек) визуальный стиль, атипичные персонажи.
+ Есть возможность нелинейного прохождения (до 4х вариантов).
+ Головоломки, их много, интересны, вариативны, постепенно возрастающей сложности.
+ Забавная система подсказок в виде Лисы-феи Типси.

Отрицательное:
- Хотя в сюжете есть некий твист, а в лоре некий эпос, в целом и тот, и другой представлены скудно. 
- Некоторые головоломки слишком просты, другие же вызывают скрип зубов из-за решения на скорость.
- Боевая система проста, однообразна и иногда кажется лишней.
- Отсутствие голосовой озвучки. Музыка хоть и ненавязчива, но и незапоминается.
- Иногда не хватает понимания всех возможностей орудие, отчего после получаса мучений на одной локации  возникает вопрос: *А что, так можно было ? Почему мне не показали данную особенность ?*.

P.S. Если тебе понравилась эта игра, то посмотри и другие от данного разработчика - Ludosity, они все оцененны положительно и обладают фирменным стилем.
